Dow Jones Factiva

 Dow Jones

Freddie Says Loss Narrows
By Nick Timiraos
449 words
9 August 2011
The Wall Street Journal
J
C2
English
(Copyright (c) 2011, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

Freddie Mac posted a $2.1 billion loss for the second quarter, down from a year-ago loss of $4.7 billion.

The mortgage-finance giant paid $1.6 billion to the government and asked for $1.5 billion in new aid during the quarter. That marked the fourth consecutive period in which, after making its regular dividend payment to the government, the company didn't generate a loss for U.S. taxpayers.

The report came on the same day that Standard & Poor's downgraded the long-term credit rating of Freddie Mac and its larger cousin, Fannie Mae, to AA-plus from AAA. That stemmed from S&P's decision late Friday to cut the credit rating of the U.S. government, which effectively nationalized Fannie and Freddie three years ago.

The U.S. government has pledged to keep Fannie and Freddie afloat by injecting unlimited amounts of money into both in order to keep mortgage markets functioning. Fannie and Freddie are required to pay a 10% dividend to the government on those infusions.

In the past year, Freddie Mac has absorbed $2.1 billion in government aid to cover, in part, the cost of $6.4 billion in payments to the Treasury. The cost of the government's bailout of Freddie stands at $51.9 billion. Fannie Mae last week reported a net loss of $2.9 billion for the second quarter and asked the government for another $2.8 billion on Friday, bringing its tab to $89 billion.

Freddie's quarterly loss stemmed in part from losses on derivatives that are used to hedge the firm's exposure to swings in interest rates. The firm also added $2.5 billion to its loss reserves, up from a $2 billion addition in the first quarter.

While mortgage rates have fallen to new lows in the past two weeks, Chief Executive Charles "Ed" Haldeman Jr. warned that "labor market weakness and households' worries about their financial security" had damped home sales, prompting a "cautious" outlook.

While both companies ran up huge losses in the two years following the government takeover, Freddie has shown glimmers of stability in recent quarters. That stems in part from the size of its loan book, which is about 40% smaller than Fannie's, and because Freddie guaranteed fewer risky loans than Fannie.

At the end of June, about 3.5% of mortgages guaranteed by Freddie Mac were 90 days or more past due, compared with 4.08% at Fannie Mae. Fannie has about $200 billion in nonperforming home loans, compared with roughly $115 billion at Freddie.

License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service[http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=wjco20110809000111]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document J000000020110809e78900031


Building Permits Jump
By Joseph De Avila
602 words
9 August 2011
The Wall Street Journal
J
A17
English
(Copyright (c) 2011, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

New construction permits in New York are on the rise, a sign that the city's ailing construction industry may be picking up steam.

Construction permits for new buildings, alterations and demolition rose by about 12% during the first half of 2011 compared with the same period last year, according to new data from the city Department of Buildings. Demolitions -- generally an indicator that developers are starting projects -- jumped 14%.

Large-scale projects have been hard to come by in post-financial crisis New York. The boost in new permits is an encouraging sign for the industry, but the numbers don't indicate whether these are large or small construction jobs.

And while the number of construction permits is an improvement from 2010 and 2009, they are still about 6% below the figures of the first half of 2008.

"More construction permits mean more people are going to work," said Buildings Commissioner Robert LiMandri.

New York's construction industry has been plagued by high unemployment since the downturn began. During the first quarter of this year, there were 101,200 people employed by the industry, according to New York Building Congress, a trade association. That's the lowest level since 1998.

"I think it's getting worse for us," said Jack Kittle, political director for DC 9 International Union of Painters and Allied Trades. Good construction workers who are usually in high demand typically don't show up to union halls unless they are out of work, he said. "That's when you know things are bad. I see a lot of them right now," he said.

Private developers are still having a tough time convincing lenders to finance big projects, said Richard T. Anderson, president of the New York Building Congress.

That has made the construction industry more reliant on public institutions such as the New York City School Construction Authority and the City University of New York for work, he added.

The rise in construction permits is "certainly a positive sign," but the improvement has been undercut by the number of stalled sites in the city, Mr. Anderson said.

There are about 650 stalled sites across the five boroughs, according to the Department of Buildings.

"They have been at a stubbornly high level," Mr. Anderson said.

Some projects have come back to life in recent months. Extell Development Co.'s 34-story International Gem Tower in the Diamond District started work recently after months of inactivity, said John Livingston, president of Tishman Construction Corp., which is building the tower.

More projects are on the way, he said. Tishman has begun preconstruction at the Donnell Library on West 53rd Street, where Starwood Capital Group and Tribeca Associates plan to build a $400 million hotel and condo tower.

"We got a lot in the queue," Mr. Livingston said.

In 2009 and 2010, there was a lot of pessimism among developers, but that has begun to shift, he said.

"There is a renewed confidence. We are cautiously optimistic about the future," he said.

Richard Lambeck, head of the construction management program at New York University's Schack Institute of Real Estate, said the increase in permits is encouraging.

But, he added, a bounce-back is far from certain.

The recent debt showdown in Washington, D.C., and plunging financial markets may give already-jittery lenders further cause for caution, Mr. Lambeck said.

"A lot of these [larger] projects are waiting for the economy to turn around," he said. "I think they are going to wait a little longer."

License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service[http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=wjco20110809000064]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document J000000020110809e7890001r


Careers
New Dean to Confront State Budget Woes
By Melissa Korn
775 words
4 August 2011
The Wall Street Journal Online
WSJO
English
Copyright 2011 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

François Ortalo-Magné takes the helm of the Wisconsin School of Business next month following Wisconsin's contentious battle over collective bargaining rights for public-employee unions, which has presented challenges for the state university system.

Mr. Ortalo-Magné, however, sees those challenges as opportunities. The business school suffered some loss of funding—a small fraction of the nearly $100 million cut made to parent school University of Wisconsin-Madison. In exchange, the university system wrested some control over hiring and budgets from the state.

Challenges are nothing new for Mr. Ortalo-Magné, who became chair of the school's Real Estate and Urban Land Economics department in 2008 in the wake of the housing crisis. He helped navigate the program through the disappearance of development-sector jobs and the rise of the foreclosure industry.

He also helped launch the school's Global Real Estate Master program, teaming up with schools in Hong Kong, Costa Rica and his native France. Now on a larger stage, he is looking to continue expanding Wisconsin's international reach.

Mr. Ortalo-Magné spoke with The Wall Street Journal about changes in the real-estate job market, the state's budget crisis and his push to globalize the business school.

Edited excerpts:

WSJ: Your expertise is in real estate, a tumultuous industry. Why would someone study it these days?

Mr. Ortalo-Magné: We are getting students who want to move to leadership positions in that industry. These are people involved on all sides, from developers, people interested in land use, all the way to people investing in the product—equity and debt—and then people investing in investments. REITs [real-estate investment trusts], for example, [and] CMBSs [commercial mortgage backed securities].

WSJ: What's changed [post-crisis] in terms of who you're getting and where they're going?

Mr. Ortalo-Magné: Who we are getting [hasn't changed much]. The industry is obviously a little more discriminating in terms of who they hire. Development has slowed down a lot. The whole CMBS industry was [hiring] students during the boom years, and there's much less activity on that side of the market.

Now there are people working on foreclosures; that was not that big during the boom years. In '07 we started [offering] more advanced topics in real-estate law to prepare our students for these types of issues.

WSJ: Bigger picture, there's a lot of uncertainty [in the job market]. How can you prepare your students for that?

Mr. Ortalo-Magné: The best thing we can do for our students is help them understand how we frame questions. As a business school within a research university, we have a mandate to not just teach what's in the textbook, but to teach students how to think about observations. If you can equip them with that, they'll be equipped for whatever they face.

WSJ: How much do the financial problems of the state affect you?

Mr. Ortalo-Magné: At this point, the budgetary situation at the state level has not affected our strategy. If anything, it's actually opened new doors for us. As part of the conversation about our budget, we've had conversations about getting more flexibility from state regulations.

It's about aligning faculty to focus on what they are best at by complementing them with the optimal type of skill mix. [That] doesn't match what the state structure was forcing us to follow. A very simple example: Providing faculty with someone who can type really fast is no longer as useful as it used to be.

WSJ: You were central to building the school's international partnerships. What's the next step?

Mr. Ortalo-Magné: We want to reinvent—or to invent our kind of—partnership. I do not see right now putting up a campus on another continent. However, we are in conversations with other business schools in how can we provide expertise to serve the needs that they see on other continents in exactly the same way that we are doing right now in real estate. I think there is room for innovating in how we think about outsourcing in the business of education.

WSJ: What are the cons of outsourcing some of the education?

Mr. Ortalo-Magné: The way we handle this is by aligning ourselves in the choice of partners. You have to align values, nothing replaces that. Those partnerships which we have put in place so far, they have built upon friendships between faculty across institutions.

Write to Melissa Korn at melissa.korn@dowjones.com[mailto:melissa.korn@dowjones.com]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document WSJO000020110803e784008hm


Real Estate
Maura Webber Sadovi; Tall Order in the Big Easy
By Maura Webber Sadovi
864 words
3 August 2011
The Wall Street Journal Online
WSJO
English
Copyright 2011 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

A 25-year-old real-estate investment trust, which has sparked some criticism for its strong appetite for acquisitions, has agreed to buy New Orleans's tallest skyscraper for $107 million, according to people familiar with the property.

CommonWealth REIT, of Newton, Mass., is buying the 51-story office building named One Shell Square from MetLife Inc., the people said. CommonWealth and MetLife declined to comment on the deal.

The deal reflects the pressure many buyers are facing to push into new territories for buildings as competition has made major market bargains scarcer. "Things have been getting a little more challenging," John Popeo, CommonWealth's chief financial officer, told an investors' conference in June, according to a transcript.

CommonWealth's buying spree—and its decision to finance it, in part, by selling new shares—also has attracted new scrutiny to the REIT. CommonWealth has spent more than $2 billion scooping up dozens of office buildings through the downturn, making it one of the biggest buyers of U.S. office properties in this cycle, according to Real Capital Analytics. Among its other deals: Earlier this year it paid $171 million for Office Depot Inc.'s Boca Raton, Fla., headquarters.

Early in the recovery the company's buying binge was cheered by some analysts, but rising prices and concerns about tenants signing new leases at lower rents has raised some red flags. Stephen Swett, an analyst with Morgan Keegan, questions the company's move last month to issue about 11.5 million new common shares for $24, a discount to the $30 share value that Mr. Swett estimates the company's underlying portfolio is worth. "You're essentially selling your own real estate at a cheap price to buy [buildings] at a market price," Mr. Swett says.

Tim Bonang, a CommonWealth spokesman, said issuing shares dilutes the stock's value in the short term, but that the company should benefit because the money allows it to turn its portfolio away from suburban buildings to office properties in central business districts where tenant demand is expected to be stronger.

CommonWealth is no stranger to criticism as a so-called externally managed REIT. In most REITs, the managers work for the same company that owns the properties. But, with externally managed REITs, the property is managed by separate companies. Sometimes, according to critics, the interests of the managers conflict with the interests of the REITs' shareholders.

In CommonWealth's case, the company's day-to-day operations are managed by Reit Management & Research LLC, owned by Barry Portnoy and his son Adam Portnoy. Both are on CommonWealth's board of trustees, and Adam Portnoy is president of both CommonWealth and Reit Management.

Some analysts are concerned the prospect of increased business could spur Reit Management to buy properties even when they aren't a good fit for CommonWealth.

Green Street Advisors, a Newport Beach, Calif. research firm, doesn't follow externally managed real-estate firms because of such conflicts. "The fees get bigger as the company gets bigger, but not necessarily as the company gets better," says Michael Knott, a managing director at Green Street.

CommonWealth has underperformed the FTSE NAREIT All Equity REITs Index , a broad group of REIT stocks. CommonWealth's total annualized one-year return as of July 27 was 1.3% compared with 22.82% for the index, and the company's 15-year annualized return was 3.4% compared with 10.8% for the index, according to Green Street.

But Mr. Bonang points out that investors who have held stock since the company's inception in 1986 have gotten an 8.5% average annual return. He also notes that the REIT has sold more than $1 billion in assets since the beginning of 2008.

In a February earnings conference call, Adam Portnoy said the company has been prudent in its growth. "…Many of the peers that have an internally managed structure have engaged in far more aggressive growth tactics than we have ever used," Mr. Portnoy said, according to a transcript.

In the New Orleans deal, CommonWealth is paying about $89 a square foot. At the peak of the market, some New Orleans property sold in as high as $200 a square foot, according to Real Capital. Evan Stone of Jones Lang LaSalle represented MetLife in the current sale.

But, for its lower price, CommonWealth is taking on some market risk.

The occupancy of the building has fallen to about 88%. One Shell Square is named after Shell Oil Co., the U.S. arm of Royal Dutch Shell PLC, and roughly half the building is occupied by Royal Dutch employees. But that lease expires in 2016, according to people familiar with the property. When One Shell was built by Texas developer Gerald Hines in the 1970s, New Orleans could rely pretty confidently in the energy industry. But that has changed in recent years as companies have relocated workers to Houston and the suburbs, leaving landlords looking to technology companies and other industries to fill the holes.

Write to Maura Webber Sadovi at maura.sadovi@wsj.com [mailto:maura.sadovi@wsj.com]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document WSJO000020110803e7830001l


The Property Report
Deal of the Week: Tall Order in the Big Easy
By Maura Webber Sadovi
810 words
3 August 2011
The Wall Street Journal
J
C8
English
(Copyright (c) 2011, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

A 25-year-old real-estate investment trust, which has sparked some criticism for its strong appetite for acquisitions, has agreed to buy New Orleans's tallest skyscraper for $107 million, according to people familiar with the property.

CommonWealth REIT, of Newton, Mass., is buying the 51-story office building named One Shell Square from MetLife Inc., the people said. CommonWealth and MetLife declined to comment on the deal.

The deal reflects the pressure many buyers are facing to push into new territories for buildings as competition has made major market bargains scarcer. "Things have been getting a little more challenging," John Popeo, CommonWealth's chief financial officer, told an investors' conference in June, according to a transcript.

CommonWealth's buying spree -- and its decision to finance it, in part, by selling new shares -- also has attracted new scrutiny to the REIT. CommonWealth has spent more than $2 billion scooping up dozens of office buildings through the downturn, making it one of the biggest buyers of U.S. office properties in this cycle, according to Real Capital Analytics. Among its other deals: Earlier this year it paid $171 million for Office Depot Inc.'s Boca Raton, Fla., headquarters.

Early in the recovery the company's buying binge was cheered by some analysts, but rising prices and concerns about tenants signing new leases at lower rents has raised some red flags. "You're essentially selling your own real estate at a cheap price to buy [buildings] at a market price," Mr. Swett says.

CommonWealth is no stranger to criticism as a so-called externally managed REIT. In most REITs, the managers work for the same company that owns the properties. But, with externally managed REITs, the property is managed by separate companies. Sometimes, according to critics, the interests of the managers conflict with the interests of the REITs' shareholders.

In CommonWealth's case, the company's day-to-day operations are managed by Reit Management & Research LLC, owned by Barry Portnoy and his son Adam Portnoy. Both are on CommonWealth's board of trustees, and Adam Portnoy is president of both CommonWealth and Reit Management.

Some analysts are concerned the prospect of increased business could spur Reit Management to buy properties even when they aren't a good fit for CommonWealth.

Green Street Advisors, a Newport Beach, Calif. research firm, doesn't follow externally managed real-estate firms because of such conflicts. "The fees get bigger as the company gets bigger, but not necessarily as the company gets better," says Michael Knott, a managing director at Green Street.

CommonWealth has underperformed the FTSE NAREIT All Equity REITs Index, a broad group of REIT stocks. CommonWealth's total annualized one-year return as of July 27 was 1.3% compared with 22.82% for the index, and the company's 15-year annualized return was 3.4% compared with 10.8% for the index, according to Green Street.

But Mr. Bonang points out that investors who have held stock since the company's inception in 1986 have gotten an 8.5% average annual return. He also notes that the REIT has sold more than $1 billion in assets since the beginning of 2008.

In a February earnings conference call, Adam Portnoy said the company has been prudent in its growth. ". . . Many of the peers that have an internally managed structure have engaged in far more aggressive growth tactics than we have ever used," Mr. Portnoy said, according to a transcript.

In the New Orleans deal, CommonWealth is paying about $89 a square foot. At the peak of the market, some New Orleans property sold in as high as $200 a square foot, according to Real Capital. Evan Stone of Jones Lang LaSalle represented MetLife in the current sale.

But, for its lower price, CommonWealth is taking on some market risk.

The occupancy of the building has fallen to about 88%. One Shell Square is named after Shell Oil Co., the U.S. arm of Royal Dutch Shell PLC, and roughly half the building is occupied by Royal Dutch employees. But that lease expires in 2016, according to people familiar with the property.

Document J000000020110803e7830000d


U.S. News: Factories Slow Pace As Orders Contract
By Conor Dougherty
522 words
2 August 2011
The Wall Street Journal
J
A6
English
(Copyright (c) 2011, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

The U.S. manufacturing sector barely expanded in July, a sign that a onetime driver of the economy is waning along with the recovery.

The new reports echoes earlier ones, which show that after a long cycle of rebuilding inventories, factories in the U.S. and overseas are curtailing production amid softer demand.

The Institute for Supply Management's manufacturing index -- a survey of purchasing managers that gauges business activity at factories and other industrial plants -- was at 50.9% in July, down from 55.3% in June. Any reading above 50 indicates expansion, so the July level -- the lowest since July 2009, the first month of the recovery -- portrays a sector inching into the second half of the year.

"It's definitely not a good start," said Brad Holcomb, chairman of the ISM manufacturing report.

The report's details contained more troubling news: All the index's components, from production to supplier deliveries and employment, fell over the month.

A particular concern was the new-orders index, a gauge of future activity, which fell to 49.2, meaning the level of new orders contracted for the first time since June 2009.

"We shouldn't be at a point in the recovery where you're getting a big pullback in the pipeline of activity," said David Greenlaw, an economist with Morgan Stanley. He added that the report raised questions about many economists' forecasts -- including his own -- that growth would pick up in the second half.

The only spots of good news were that exports increased, if slightly, and the ISM's price index fell to 59 from 68 -- an indication that energy and raw-material costs are easing, giving manufacturers some relief on squeezed profit margins.

Some of the weakness can be explained by uncertainty over the debt-ceiling debate, which some manufacturers said was a factor, according to the ISM report.

Also, supply disruptions stemming from the March earthquake in Japan are still playing out.

Still, the manufacturing slowdown isn't limited to the U.S. A global purchasing-managers index assembled by economists at J.P. Morgan Chase & Co. slid to a two-year low in July. The 1.7-point drop put the index at 50.6 -- barely above expansion, just like the ISM reading.

While Japan was growing briskly as its factories snap back from a retrenchment following the quake, manufacturers in both developed and emerging economies were seeing production slow, said Joseph Lupton, an economist at J.P. Morgan Chase & Co.

A separate report Monday from the Commerce Department showed construction spending rose 0.2% in June, the third-consecutive monthly gain, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $772.3 billion. The previous month's gain was revised up. Despite the improvement, construction spending remains stuck at recession-era levels.

Monday's report showed a monthly gain in private spending outpaced a decline in spending on government projects, which have become a drag as state and local governments cut back to close budget gaps.

License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service[http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=wjco20110802000030]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document J000000020110802e7820000t


FRIDAY JOURNAL --- Greetings From My Own Private Island --- Wealthy buyers are flocking to a little-known archipelago in the Bahamas, fueling an island building boom; Privacy comes at a price: Owning a personal island means importing everything from water to electricity
By Candace Jackson
2550 words
29 July 2011
The Wall Street Journal
J
D1
English
(Copyright (c) 2011, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

Roughly 300 miles off the coast of South Florida is a string of mostly uninhabited small islands amid clear blue water and coral reefs on a limestone plateau. There's virtually no nightlife, no major airports, no celebrity chef restaurants. There are also no neighbors. That remoteness is attracting a rarefied group of wealthy entertainers and name-brand CEOs. In the world of high-end real estate, privacy is an increasingly prized amenity.

Islands in Exuma Cays, a 365-island archipelago in the Bahamas, have recently sold to producer/director Tyler Perry, spiritual leader Aga Khan and country singers Tim McGraw and Faith Hill, joining earlier arrivals Johnny Depp, David Copperfield and LVMH Chairman and Chief Executive Bernard Arnault. Ms. Hill and Mr. McGraw are in the final stages of construction on a roughly 15,000-square-foot, four-bedroom home on their 17-acre island, Goat Cay, which they purchased a few years ago, according to people familiar with the project. Mr. Perry bought a 25-acre island called White Bay Cay as well as a nearby seven-acre island in 2009, and is currently building a tropical/Balinese-style home with several guest bungalows.

Despite the weak economy, the number of millionaires in the U.S. and their combined net worth hit record highs in 2010, with investible assets up more than 8.4% from 2009, according to the World Wealth Report by Merrill Lynch and Capgemini. Several record-breaking real-estate sales this year have buoyed optimism in the ultra-high end of the market, including the $85 million sale of a Los Angeles estate owned by Candy Spelling earlier this month. In March, a Russian buyer paid $100 million for a home in Silicon Valley, the highest price ever paid for a single-family home.

Island development projects can take years -- at least one under way now involves 150 workers. Locals say one of the biggest private resort projects under construction in the Exumas is a compound whose principal investors are the co-founders of California-based retailer Fry's Electronics, brothers John, Randy and David Fry and Kathy Kolder. On a group of eight islands known as Bock Cay, the project calls for a staff village with about 35 homes for employees, a main clubhouse and six guest estates built in various styles, including an Italian villa. Fifteen hundred palm trees have been imported. One unusual private-island feature in the works: an 18-hole Nick Faldo-designed golf course with at least one drive that goes over the ocean to reach a hole on a nearby island that's also part of the property.

A spokesman for Fry's says an opening date hasn't yet been set, and that the island will likely be available as a very high-end rental in the model of Sir Richard Branson's Necker Island in the British Virgin Islands. (Weekly rates at Mr. Branson's island start at $54,500 per night for up to 28 guests.)

The Exuma Cays (pronounced "Keys" by most locals and regulars) have many of the ingredients for a destination for the extremely wealthy: sandy beaches, turquoise water and limited development possibilities -- 90% of the islands are either uninhabitable or protected as part of a 176-square-mile marine park. The growing ease of staying connected with cable and the Internet, as well as improved desalination and diesel-generator technology, have also made the islands more attractive, says Tom Lawson, a resident who has developed, owned or managed several private-island properties there.

The relatively large number of islands makes the Exumas generally more affordable than other exclusive destinations like the Seychelles, says Farhad Vladi, the Germany-based founder of Vladi Private Islands, a private-island real-estate company. Although prices for islands in the Exumas have doubled in the last decade, the Seychelles cost even more because of their scarcity and extreme privacy, with most basic islands selling for around $30 million.

And the Exumas' relative lack of tourist infrastructure has kept them somewhat under the radar -- people often arrive by yacht, sea plane or helicopter -- although they are relatively close to the U.S. "I can be there for three or four days and you really don't see anybody," says Eddie Irvine, a former Formula One racecar driver from Northern Ireland who purchased an undeveloped island in the area about a year ago.

Steve and Patrick Harrington, former investment banker brothers originally from Chicago, have purchased islands in the Exumas for investment and development purposes. One they've recently put on the market for $22 million has a 4,000-square-foot house, two miles of coastline and 145 acres of land purchased in 2006. Steve Harrington says he's drawn to the English-speaking, stable Bahamian government and the pristine "Corona commercial look."

Building a luxury home on a remote island means importing everything from electricity to cellphone towers to water purifiers. Eduardo Martinez, a Miami-based architect who has designed homes and interiors for several island owners in the Exuma Cays, says that the first step is dredging a marina, then building temporary houses and dining facilities for staff, the majority of whom legally have to be local Bahamians. A typical project takes at least 2 1/2 years. "The closest lumber yard is in Fort Lauderdale," says Mr. Martinez. "You can't run to the corner and get nails and concrete."

Building materials must be imported on large barges, which take about two days to make the trip from Florida, weather permitting. For islands without an existing power source, electricity comes from diesel generators, which also must be imported. According to Ed Bosarge, the principal beneficiary of the trust that owns a land-lease and building rights to Yonder Cay, just south of Mr. Depp's island, commonly used diesel generators can generate a power bill as high as $1 million a year.

The real-estate bust did affect these shores, with islands sitting longer and often selling for lower prices. An unnamed, 681-acre island with an airstrip, a seven-bedroom, six-bathroom timber-frame main house, a gym and staff buildings has been on the market for $55 million for 2 1/2 years. Earlier this month, it was offered in a sealed-bid auction. The listing broker, George Damianos, says two reasonable offers have been received, but a sale hasn't been finalized.

One of the least expensive on the market now is Nicolas Cage's former island, Leaf Cay, which remains completely undeveloped and is available for $8.5 million. At the top end of the market is Cave Cay, a 250-acre island priced at $110 million that has its own harbor and runway. Listing broker John Christie, of H.G. Christie, says there are several buildings on the property, some of which are not yet completed. He says it has been on the market for about a year and the sellers are open to offers for less than the listing price.

"It's definitely a buyer's market right now," says Kevin Cross, a Nassau-based real-estate broker. But he and others say buyers are emerging. "We're getting real buyers looking in the $30 million to $50 million price range," says Mr. Christie.

Movie stars, royalty and old-money families have yachted around the Exumas and vacationed on the main island, Great Exuma, since at least the 1950s. On the market right now is Children's Bay Cay, the $37.5 million former vacation playground of Jessica Tandy and Hume Cronyn, who vacationed on the island in their movie-making heydays in the 1950s and '60s. It's been owned by heirs to the Johnson & Johnson family fortune. They couldn't be reached for comment.

During the 1970s and 1980s, however, the area's reputation was marred when drug smugglers used the islands as a key trafficking point to smuggle cocaine to the U.S. from South America. Norman's Cay was once the headquarters for Medellin cartel leader Carlos Lehder, before he was arrested in 1987. The Bahamian government eventually stabilized, and tourism in the country began to thrive in the late 1990s with the construction of massive resorts on Nassau and Paradise Island. (Another massive resort, Baha Mar, a $3.4 billion hotel and casino, is currently under construction in Nassau.)

Perhaps the best-known private-island compound is magician David Copperfield's 700-acre resort Musha Cay, which is spread across 11 islands. He purchased several of the islands a little over five years ago for more than $50 million and spent almost another $30 million gut-renovating and expanding his ultra-high-end resort there. There are five guest houses with private beaches, an outdoor movie theater and an on-site staff of 30 that includes a masseuse and sommelier. Visitors can rent the entire property, which has 40 private beaches and sleeps up to 24, for rates starting at $37,500 a night, including meals and beverages. (Penelope Cruz was married there, as was Google co-founder Sergey Brin.)

Mr. Copperfield describes it as a place where he can "create magic in three dimensions" and where a stay can include an optional, interactive treasure hunt where he says guests are immersed in a "living movie." (Dozens of actors and illusionists are imported to play pirates.) Recent additions to the resort include trained macaws that pick up Musha Cay's refuse and a "secret village," opening soon, where visitors can interact with tame monkeys.

The Exumas' newest neighbors could be moving in soon. Ms. Hill and Mr. McGraw's home on Goat Cay, a previously undeveloped island, is nearly completed and includes a single-story tropical-plantation-style main house with a lookout tower, and three smaller homes for a manager and staff, according to people familiar with the project. A representative for the couple declined to comment.

Tyler Perry's island retreat, White Bay Cay, was also previously undeveloped and consists of a 25-acre island and a seven-acre island relatively close by; both are near Mr. Depp's island. (The 25-acre island was listed at one point for $7 million.) The spread, which is still being completed, includes a 14,000-square-foot main house and five to six smaller guest bungalows. There's also a spa, a tennis court and a marina. Mr. Perry's representative said he had no comment.

The Aga Khan, the Muslim spiritual leader and philanthropist, purchased 349-acre Bell Island in 2009 for $100 million, according to public records. Gail Lockhart Charles, the Bahamas-based representative for the Aga Khan, said that the existing homes on the island -- flat, concrete structures built to maximize water views and minimize potential hurricane damage -- are being renovated to create a "private family retreat." Also in the works is a native-plant nursery and landscaping with indigenous plants and flowers. Ms. Lockhart says the project is scheduled to be finished in about six months.

In recent years, owners have been toning down the glitzy look. The latest trend is to build slightly less opulent homes that use solar power and are self-sustainable, Mr. Martinez says, though that can add to the overall cost. (Johnny Depp's island, Little Hall's Pond Cay, has at least some solar power. A representative for Mr. Depp said he had no comment.)

Former race-car driver Mr. Irvine says on his island, electricity will be provided by solar panels and solar-powered batteries; transportation will be by kayak or bicycle. Mr. Irvine says he's working on a water-making facility and plans to try to source most of what he eats while there from the island itself. "If you want to be living the Palm Beach lifestyle, live in Palm Beach," he says.

Mr. Bosarge of Yonder Cay claims the island will be the first of its size in the Caribbean to be entirely powered by renewable energy. The 70-acre island now has 10 wind-turbine generators, solar power with backup batteries and a reverse-osmosis water-purification system that will make 21,000 gallons of water a day.

To complete Yonder Cay by its November deadline, the project's Houston-based chief operating officer, David Houston, says there's currently staff of 150 on the island, 110 of whom are living there in temporary housing. The rest are ferried back and forth to a populated island, with existing housing, in the morning and evening.

---

Stars of the Sea, From Branson to Gibson

Leonardo DiCaprio

Blackadore Caye, Belize

The actor's island is 104 acres. There were plans at one point to build an eco-resort there.

Sir Richard Branson

Necker Island, British Virgin Islands

The Virgin Group founder owns this Caribbean island, which he uses as a vacation spot and as a very high-end rental.

Celine Dion

Ile Gagnon, Quebec

The pop star's island is located in the Mille Iles River. There's a grand French-chateau-style mansion on the property.

Johnny Depp

Little Hall's Pond Cay, Bahamas

The actor has owned the island for a number of years. At least some of the island is powered by solar energy.

Mel Gibson

Mago Island, Fiji

The 5,400-acre island is owned by the actor, who purchased it from a Japanese corporation for a reported $15 million.

---

For Sale: Five Islands For Under $1 Million

Barnard Island, Citrus County, Fla., $55,000

This undeveloped 5.2-acre island sits in the Tsala Apopka Lake near Hernando, about an hour and 45 minutes from Walt Disney World. Thick with trees and wildlife, it is buildable land, according to the listing agent. The price has been lowered from $93,000.

42 Birch Island, Greenville, Maine, $650,000

This six-acre island on Moosehead Lake has a two-bedroom, one-bath main house and a one-bedroom guesthouse. There's no electricity, but there is a land line. Five miles offshore, it comes with two motorboats and a canoe. The island was originally listed for $1.5 million.

Diamond Cay, Honduras, $650,000

Surrounded by blue sea and coral reefs, this 1.4-acre island is about 20 minutes off East Harbor on the Honduras coast. It's about a half-mile to the nearby island of Utila, which has an airport. There are a few rustic cabins on the island, but no water or power.

Dokis Marina Island, Ontario, C$225,000 (US$237,000)

It's a short boat ride from the Dokis Marina to the dock on this half-acre island in the French River-Lake Nipissing area. A one-bedroom cottage has propane heat; another cabin sleeps four.

Isla Paraiso, Chile, $850,000

This island covering approximately 4.9 acres comes with a furnished three-bedroom house, electricity and water from a spring. The island is located in Lake Calafquen; a motorboat and a rowboat are included.

-- Sarah Tilton

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Corporate News: Horton, Pulte Report Weak Quarters
By Dawn Wotapka and Robbie Whelan
454 words
29 July 2011
The Wall Street Journal
J
B3
English
(Copyright (c) 2011, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

Two of the nation's largest home builders reported weak quarterly financial results Thursday, but their stocks rallied after an industry report indicated future sales could be stronger.

The positive news came as the National Association of Realtors reported that its index of pending home sales, which tracks how many home buyers have signed purchase contracts, jumped 2.4% in June from the previous month to 90.9, the index's highest reading since March 2011. When compared with a year earlier, pending sales were up 20%.

Buyers who sign sale contracts often complete their purchases within 60 days.

The rise in pending home sales could suggest "a stabilizing market in coming months," said Doug Duncan, the chief economist of the government-backed mortgage company Fannie Mae. But he cautioned that contract signings don't always become closings and that contract cancellations have been rising in recent months. He also warned that the labor market will have to improve before housing can truly recover.

There were tentative signs that such improvements could be coming. The Labor Department reported Thursday that initial jobless claims fell below 400,000 for the first time since early April.

Although claims remain high, economists generally think the economy is adding more jobs than it is shedding once the weekly claims figure falls below 400,000.

Those reports helped to lift sentiment among investors, who awakened Thursday morning to the weak news from home builders. Hours before the stock market opened, Fort Worth, Texas-based D.R. Horton, the nation's largest home builder by annual closings, reported a fiscal-third-quarter profit of $28.7 million, or nine cents a share, down from $50.5 million, or 16 cents a share a year earlier.

Horton's closest competitor, PulteGroup Inc., based in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., reported a second-quarter loss of $55.4 million, compared with net income of $76.3 million, or 20 cents a share, a year earlier.

The builders suffered from lower revenue and charges. Buyers, who can no longer tap the federal home-buyer tax credit, closed on fewer new homes built by Pulte and Horton in the most recent quarter than they had a year earlier. "Simply put, we need more jobs and better consumer confidence before meaningful recovery can occur," Pulte Chief Executive Richard Dugas said in a conference call Thursday morning with analysts and investors.

Still, by midday, builder stocks were generally showing gains. Pulte's stock ultimately closed at $6.80 a share, down 2.86% from Wednesday's close. Horton closed at $11.90 a share, up 2.59%.

License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service[http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=wjco20110729000046]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document J000000020110729e77t00010


U.S. News: Home Sales, Prices Reflect Malaise
By Wesley Lowery
605 words
27 July 2011
The Wall Street Journal
J
A3
English
(Copyright (c) 2011, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

Home prices and sales of new homes lost ground in recent months, with real-estate agents and builders saying the debt-ceiling debate in Washington is rattling an already-fragile market.

According to the Standard & Poor's Case-Shiller home price index, released Tuesday, prices for existing homes in 20 major U.S. cities fell 4.5% in May from a year earlier, with declines stretching from coast to coast. Only Washington, D.C., saw a year-over-year increase. Compared with April, prices in May were virtually unchanged on a seasonally adjusted basis.

"If you're looking for the light at the end of the tunnel, we don't have it," said David Blitzer, chairman of S&P's index committee. "We all agree the market ain't going anyplace at all."

On a month-to-month, seasonally adjusted basis, prices were up in nine cities, led by Washington (up 1.4%) and Boston (up 1.2%). Prices in 11 cities were lower, led by Detroit (down 3.4%) and Tampa (down 1.5%).

Separately, the Census Bureau reported Tuesday that new-home sales fell 1% in June from a month earlier to an annual rate of 312,000 units. That was weaker than many economists were expecting and puts the current sales pace below last year's total of 323,000 sales, which was the lowest annual total on record.

Economists said the housing market continues to be hampered by tight lending standards that are keeping buyers on the sidelines, as well as by high unemployment -- the national rate now stands at 9.2%. The political battle between Republicans and Democrats in Washington over raising the debt ceiling has injected fresh worries to the market.

Consumers, wary that borrowing costs could increase, are canceling purchase contracts and delaying making a decision until the situation in Washington is resolved. This is "a new curve ball in the housing market," said Jason Haber, chief executive of Rubicon Property, a Manhattan-based brokerage. "It just adds uncertainty."

Even in Washington -- the only market to show price increases from a year earlier according to the S&P Case-Shiller index -- some realtors warn that conditions are changing and buyers are starting to worry about government layoffs.

"I've got listings from $960,000 to $200,000 and nothing is moving," said Chuck Riley, a realtor with RE/MAX Allegiance in Washington, D.C. "Anyone who tells you this is an easy market is lying to you."

While sales of new homes fell short of expectations, the report contained a few bright notes. The inventory of homes available for sale declined to 164,000, after seasonal adjustments. That total represents a 6.3-month supply, which is the lowest inventory level on record and shows that builders have worked through much of their excess supply.

The median sales price in June for newly constructed single-family homes climbed 7.2% from a year earlier to $235,000. Few industry watchers say they believe the rise reflects price increases by builders. Instead, they say, it likely represents a change in the mix of homes purchased, with more high-end or move-up homes selling.

Some builders are optimistic. Eric Lipar, chief executive of LGI Homes, a Houston-based builder of entry-level houses, said he sold 53 homes in June, up from 25 a year earlier. "It's going pretty well for us," he said, "but we're probably the exception."

---

Dawn Wotapka contributed to this article.

License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service[http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=wjco20110727000127]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document J000000020110727e77r00039


Business
Home Sales, Prices Reflect Malaise
By Wesley Lowery
614 words
27 July 2011
The Wall Street Journal Online
WSJO
English
Copyright 2011 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

Home prices and sales of new homes lost ground in recent months, with real-estate agents and builders saying the debt-ceiling debate in Washington is rattling an already-fragile market.

According to the Standard & Poor's Case-Shiller home price index, released Tuesday, prices for existing homes in 20 major U.S. cities fell 4.5% in May from a year earlier, with declines stretching from coast to coast. Only Washington, D.C., saw a year-over-year increase. Compared with April, prices in May were virtually unchanged on a seasonally adjusted basis.

"If you're looking for the light at the end of the tunnel, we don't have it," said David Blitzer, chairman of S&P's index committee, "We all agree the market ain't going anyplace at all."

On a month-to-month, seasonally adjusted basis, prices were up in nine cities, led by Washington (up 1.4%) and Boston (up 1.2%). Prices in 11 cities were lower, led by Detroit (down 3.4%) and Tampa (down 1.5%).

Separately, the Census Bureau reported Tuesday that new-home sales fell 1% in June from a month earlier to an annual rate of 312,000 units. That was weaker than many economists were expecting and puts the current sales pace below last year's total of 323,000 sales, which was the lowest annual total on record.

Economists said the housing market continues to be hampered by tight lending standards that are keeping buyers on the sidelines as well as high unemployment—the national rate now stands at 9.2%. The political battle between Republicans and Democrats in Washington over raising the debt ceiling has injected fresh worries to the market.

Consumers, wary that borrowing costs could increase, are canceling purchase contracts and delaying making a decision until the situation in Washinggton is resolved. This is "a new curve ball in the housing market," said Jason Haber, chief executive of Rubicon Property, a Manhattan-based brokerage. "It just adds uncertainty."

Even in Washington—the only market to show price increases from a year ago according to the S&P Case-Shiller index—some realtors warn that conditions are changing and buyers are starting to worry about government layoffs.

"I've got listings from $960,000 to $200,000 and nothing is moving," said Chuck Riley, a realtor with RE/MAX Allegiance in Washington D.C. "Anyone who tells you this is an easy market is lying to you."

While sales of new homes fell short of expectations, the report contained a few bright notes. The inventory of homes available for sale declined to 164,000, after seasonal adjustments. That total represents a 6.3-month supply, which is the lowest inventory level on record and shows that builders have worked through much of their excess supply.

The median sales price in June for newly constructed single-family homes climbed 7.2% from a year earlier to $235,000. Few industry watchers say they believe the rise reflects price increases by builders. Instead, they say, it likely represents a change in the mix of homes purchased, with more high-end or move-up homes selling.

Some builders are optimistic. Eric Lipar, chief executive of LGI Homes, a Houston-based builder of entry-level houses, said he sold 53 homes in June, up from 25 a year earlier. He credits advertising to renters in nearby communities who can own an entry-level home for less than their rent."It's going pretty well for us," he said, "but we're probably the exception."

Dawn Wotapka contributed to this article.

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document WSJO000020110726e77r0093z


U.S. News: Consumers Shrug Off Flat Housing Market
By Michael S. Derby
491 words
27 July 2011
The Wall Street Journal Europe
WSJE
10
English
(Copyright (c) 2011, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

Consumers turned more confident in July, despite persistent troubles in the labor and housing markets. Separate data indicated U.S. home prices moved sideways in May, while new-home sales dropped in June.

The Conference Board said on Tuesday that its July index of consumer confidence hit 59.5, from 57.6 in June. Economists surveyed by Dow Jones Newswires had expected the index to come in at 55.4. The report said its index of present conditions fell to 35.7, from June's 36.6, while the expectations index hit 75.4, from 71.6 last month.

Consumer sentiment has been under pressure from a wide array of bad news. Weak growth, persistently high unemployment and troubled housing markets, combined with rising food and energy prices and the crisis over U.S. government borrowing, are all conspiring to weigh on the mood of households. How much of that sentiment translates into reduced consumer spending isn't always clear, but it is not a help.

"Consumer confidence posted a modest gain in July, the result of an improvement in consumers' short-term outlook," Conference Board survey director Lynn Franco said. "Consumers' appraisal of current business and employment conditions, however, was less favorable as concerns about the labor market continue to weigh on consumers' attitudes," she said, adding that "consumers remain apprehensive about the future."

U.S. home prices rose in May from a month earlier as the spring selling season got under way, but they remained below year-earlier levels, according to the S&P Case-Shiller home-price indexes.

The Case-Shiller index of 10 major metropolitan areas rose 1.1%, and the 20-city index was up 1% in May from April. However, adjusted for seasonal factors, the 10-city figure edged up 0.1%, while the 20-city index was flat. Year-to-year, prices fell 3.6% and 4.5%, respectively.

Though 16 cities reported higher prices month-to-month, prices fell in Detroit, Las Vegas and Tampa, and were flat in Phoenix. Year-to-year, Washington, D.C., was the only market that improved, up 1.3%.

Home prices had risen sequentially in April for the first time in eight months, though most of the improvement was seen as reflecting the beginning of the spring-summer home-buying season.

"This is a seasonal period of stronger demand for houses, so monthly price increases are to be expected," said David Blitzer, chairman of S&P's index committee.

The housing market has been struggling amid high unemployment, an abundance of foreclosures and tighter mortgage requirements.

New-home sales fell unexpectedly in June. Sales declined 1% on a monthly basis to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 312,000, the Commerce Department said.

---

Tess Stynes, Alan Zibel and Jeff Bater contributed to this article.

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document WSJE000020110727e77r0000z


The Property Report: Schiphol Airport City Takes Off --- Companies Pick Amsterdam Over Airport Sites Such as Paris and Frankfurt; a 'Holland Gateway'
By Laura Stevens
889 words
27 July 2011
The Wall Street Journal Europe
WSJE
24
English
(Copyright (c) 2011, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

AMSTERDAM -- When Terremark Worldwide Inc. looked for a new European data-center location, the Miami-based information-technology company found Amsterdam's airport city to be a natural fit.

Besides having the data capabilities necessary, there are also an additional 500 global firms located at the airport city -- all potential or existing customers. Plus, Schiphol Group, the airport's owner, was able to offer an existing office building and room to expand.

Terremark, a unit of Verizon Communications Inc., started construction in February and expects to open the first stage of the new data center in September. "The airport was a bonus," adds Egbert Veldhuis, marketing manager for Terremark in Europe.

Terremark's reasons for choosing Schiphol help explain why it is emerging as one of the leading airport cities in the world. These cities are popping up throughout the world around major international airports. Their mixes of office buildings, warehouses, hotels, stores and other properties often are as tied into the rest of the world as they are into their home cities.

"Schiphol had a major head start because they understood [the airport-city concept] and leveraged it," says John Kasarda, co-author of "Aerotropolis: The Way We'll Live Next" and a professor at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. "For awhile, it had a major lead in airport-city development, although some others are starting to catch up."

The Netherlands owns about a 70% stake in Schiphol Group, which owns the airport and much of its surrounding property for a total of 540,000 square meters (5.8 million square feet). Companies that have made Schiphol their European headquarters include distribution giant ProLogis Inc., private-equity leader CVC Capital Partners and Microsoft Corp.

"It grew organically, but not by accident," says Maarten de Groof, chief commercial officer at Schiphol. "We've always had a vision for this airport city, to build and develop."

Demand for space at Schiphol have driven up its prime rents to as much as 360 euros a square meter ($49 a square foot) annually, according to Jones Lang LaSalle. By comparison, average prime rents are 335 euros a square meter ($45 a square foot) in Amsterdam Zuidas, the city's prime business district.

Companies pick Schiphol over other airport cities such as Paris, Frankfurt or Heathrow, in part because of favorable Dutch tax laws, says Sven Bertens, an Amsterdam-based researcher with Jones Lang LaSalle.

Other factors include clusters of companies in complementary business fields and a government office called "Holland Gateway" inside Schiphol's World Trade Center. It allows companies and businessmen to start paperwork for visas and other necessary documents without traveling to a myriad of buildings in the city center.

The airport sees 45.2 million passengers and transports 1.5 million tons of cargo annually. The airport city also employs 60,000 people, and the real estate is divided up nearly evenly into office and warehouse space.

The airport first founded an internal dedicated real-estate development company about a decade ago. In partnership with local municipalities, the airport has bought up much of the surrounding land.

Schiphol also owns and manages most of the buildings on airport-city property.

Owning the property makes it different from other airport cities, where outside developers often buy up and build office space, says Mr. de Groof. That gives Schiphol more maneuverability in choosing the best mix of companies, both for planning purposes and for attracting complementary businesses that boost the value of the airport location.

For example, during the downturn, Schiphol was willing to be flexible on lease terms to enable companies to keep their location in the airport city, Mr. de Groof says. Or Schiphol might accept a lower rent to attract a logistics company that would add attractive services to other tenants.

Schiphol Group had net profit of 169 million euros in 2010, up from 132 million euros in 2009. While 58% of the airport's revenue was generated by the aviation business and only 12% from real estate, aviation is much less profitable, generating only 15% of Schiphol's profit. Real estate contributes 32% of the company's profit.

Bombardier Inc. opened an Aircraft Service Center at Schiphol a little over a year ago as its second European repairs and service center location in Europe after Berlin. The facility has 45,639 square feet of hangar space and 50 employees and is increasing staffing and aircraft capabilities.

"Of course, we analyzed all those facilities and, in the end, Amsterdam won out, and we're very happy with it," says Marc Duchesne, a Bombardier spokesman. Reasons for the decision included the central location of Amsterdam and an already existing hangar ready for occupancy, he adds.

The airport has worked hard to make its terminal area more desirable as a layover destination, with a free art museum, an inside playground, upscale retail shops and a library.

The goal is to make Schiphol "the preferred" European airport, Mr. de Groof says. "As soon as you think you're there, you're on a slippery slope," adds Mr. de Groof. "There's no place for complacency."

License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service[http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=weco20110727000028]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document WSJE000020110727e77r0000r


The Property Report: In an Unexpected Turn, U.S. New-Home Sales Fall
By Alan Zibel and Jeff Bater
383 words
27 July 2011
The Wall Street Journal Asia
AWSJ
23
English
(c) 2011 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. To see the edition in which this article appeared, click here http://awsj.com.hk/factiva-ns[http://awsj.com.hk/factiva-ns]

WASHINGTON -- New-home sales fell unexpectedly in June, highlighting continuing softness in a feeble part of the U.S. economy.

Sales fell 1% on a monthly basis to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 312,000, the Commerce Department said Tuesday.

Economists surveyed by Dow Jones Newswires had forecast sales would rise 1.2% to an annual rate of 323,000. Sales are far short of healthy levels, considered to be an annual rate of around 750,000.

Home builderswere feeling good about their prospects at the start of the year. But the spring buying season has been slow. Last week, the National Association of Realtors reported that sales of existing homes fell to a seven-month low.

Despite soft demand, new-home prices increased. The median price for a new home sold last month was $235,200, up 7.2% from $219,500 a year earlier and up 5.8% on a monthly basis.

Builders steadily cut back on construction throughout the housing bust, and the supply of new homes on the market is now at 164,000, the lowest on record dating to 1963. That supply would take about six months to exhaust, roughly what economists consider healthy.

The struggling housing market has been a burden on the overall economy, though there have been some modest signs of stability in prices of late. The S&P Case-Shiller index of home prices in 20 major U.S. metropolitan areas, also released Tuesday, was up 1% in May from April. However, adjusted for seasonal factors, the 20-city index was flat.

Deeply discounted foreclosure sales have been tough competition for builders. About 2.2 million properties have been foreclosed but have yet to go up for sale, according to Lender Processing Services Inc.

Government incentives, such as a tax credit that mainly benefited first-time home buyers, helped home sales last year. But the housing market has faltered since it expired.

Sales fell 15.8% in the Northeast and 12.7% in the West. Sales were up 9.5% in the Midwest and 3.4% in the South.

License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service[http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=waco20110726000014]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document AWSJ000020110726e77r0000a


New York
Transit Agency Goes on a Diet
By Andrew Grossman
559 words
21 July 2011
The Wall Street Journal Online
WSJO
English
Copyright 2011 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is taking steps to be more frugal and salvage its budget for major projects—one of the largest sources of construction spending in the region.

The agency said Wednesday that it had cut the cost of the five-year plan by $2 billion, to $24 billion. The MTA's capital budget pays for projects such as the Second Avenue subway, new train cars and buses, subway station rehabilitation and general system maintenance that keeps trains from derailing and buses from breaking down.

Most of the savings came from changing the way the MTA administers contracts and does construction work.

The authority is also cutting the administrative payroll by 15%, reducing how frequently it runs shuttle buses when construction shuts down subway service, and pushing contractors to keep their costs down.

In return, the MTA says it's trying to address issues that contractors say make the agency an expensive customer.

Still, the authority needs to find another $9 billion to pay for all of the five-year plan, which is supposed to last until 2014 but runs out of money at the end of this year. The authority and the state Legislature agreed to fund the first two years of the plan last year.

The MTA's troubles mirror those of transit systems and highway operators around the country, which are trying to figure out how to repair aging infrastructure in the face of high debt and increasingly parsimonious state and federal governments.

"The MTA is between a rock and a hard place. The rock is the enormous capital needs of the regional transit system," said Richard Anderson, president of the New York Building Congress, a group that represents the construction industry. "The hard place is the political reality that new sources of revenue are difficult, if not impossible, in this governmental climate."

The MTA's capital budget has big implications for Mr. Anderson's members. He estimates that if the agency gets the money it's looking for, it would account for 25% of the city's construction activity next year. Another industry group, the General Contractors Association, says MTA capital spending pays for about half of the 20,000 workers employed by its members.

"Without public work, this industry would be in a depression," Mr. Anderson said. "The private side is already in a depression."

It's not clear where the MTA will find the rest of the needed money. As the MTA was cutting costs, it reduced by $1 billion its projections for funding from the federal government, which pays for about a third of the capital plan. The authority had expected Congress to pass a new transportation funding bill this year, but it has yet to do so.

The MTA has applied for a $3 billion federal loan that comes with generous repayment terms. That would help pay for projects but add to the agency's already heavy debt burden. It could also restructure its debt and borrow more.

But the agency has yet to ask for new revenue, whether in the form of taxes or higher fares.

"We recognize that there's no appetite for new taxes in New York today," MTA Chairman Jay Walder said in a statement.

Write to Andrew Grossman at andrew.grossman@wsj.com[mailto:andrew.grossman@wsj.com]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document WSJO000020110721e77l000dz


Business
Home Resales Decline Again as Buyers Hesitate
By Wesley Lowery
508 words
21 July 2011
The Wall Street Journal Online
WSJO
English
Copyright 2011 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

Existing-home sales in June fell to a seven-month low, and the number of contract cancellations soared, signaling that buyers are rethinking home purchases amid national economic uncertainty.

Sales decreased 0.8% from a month earlier to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.77 million, the National Association of Realtors said Wednesday. It was the third-straight monthly drop and puts this year's pace behind last year's 4.91 million homes sold, which had marked the weakest sales in 13 years.

The median sales price was $184,300, up 0.8% from $182,900 a year earlier.

"The housing market has been two steps forward, then two steps back," said Chris Mayer, an economics professor at Columbia University. "This is a sign of the lack of progress in developing a mortgage market that can take us past the housing crisis."

Sales were down 5.2% in the Northeast and 1.7% in the West, while other regions saw modest gains; sales were up 0.5% in the South and 1% in the Midwest. A separate report released Wednesday showed one bright spot for sales was Florida. Second-quarter home sales in Miami were up 13.5% from last year, and hit a five-year high, according to brokerage Douglas Elliman.

The overall decline in home sales "suggests that the recent deterioration in economic conditions has already hit the housing market," according to Paul Dales, senior U.S. economist at the Toronto-based Capital Economics.

Most surprising is the spike in buyers who signed contracts for properties but then pulled out. In June, 16% of NAR member realtors reported having a would-be buyer cancel their contract, up from 4% in May. Lawrence Yun, NAR's chief economist, said the realtors reporting cancellations, which is higher than the 10% seen in a typical month, is due, at least in part, to shaky consumer confidence.

"It could be that buyers are having second thoughts because of the weakened economy," Mr. Yun said.

The U.S. added very few new jobs in June, and the ongoing battle over the debt ceiling between President Barack Obama and Republicans in Congress has hurt consumer confidence.

"During the debt ceiling discussion there have been pronouncements from major politicians that we could be facing a catastrophe or a collapse," Mr. Yun says. "Anytime those kinds of dire words are used, someone who wants to make a major purchase is going to pause."

Tight credit and low appraisals also may have factored into the uptick in cancellations, but since both factors have existed for months it is unlikely they are the driving force behind the June increases, Mr. Yun said.

Economists say it will take large-scale job growth to persuade families to move out of rentals and back into houses. "With the unemployment rate still very high and rising, a major recovery is not in the cards," Mr. Dales said.

Write to Wesley Lowery at wesley.lowery@wsj.com[mailto:wesley.lowery@wsj.com]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

U.S. News: Home Resales Decline Again as Buyers Hesitate
By Wesley Lowery
478 words
21 July 2011
The Wall Street Journal
J
A4
English
(Copyright (c) 2011, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

Existing-home sales in June fell to a seven-month low, and the number of contract cancellations soared, signaling that buyers are rethinking home purchases amid national economic uncertainty.

Sales decreased 0.8% from a month earlier to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.77 million, the National Association of Realtors said Wednesday. It was the third-straight monthly drop and puts this year's pace behind last year's 4.91 million homes sold, which had marked the weakest sales in 13 years.

The median sales price was $184,300, up 0.8% from $182,900 a year earlier.

"The housing market has been two steps forward, then two steps back," said Chris Mayer, an economics professor at Columbia University. "This is a sign of the lack of progress in developing a mortgage market that can take us past the housing crisis."

Sales were down 5.2% in the Northeast and 1.7% in the West, while other regions saw modest gains; sales were up 0.5% in the South and 1% in the Midwest. A separate report released Wednesday showed one bright spot for sales was Florida. Second-quarter sales in Miami were up 13.5% from last year, and hit a five-year high, according to brokerage Douglas Elliman.

The overall decline in home sales "suggests that the recent deterioration in economic conditions has already hit the housing market," according to Paul Dales, senior U.S. economist at the Toronto-based Capital Economics.

Most surprising is the spike in buyers who signed contracts for properties but then pulled out. In June, 16% of NAR member realtors reported having a would-be buyer cancel their contract, up from 4% in May. Lawrence Yun, NAR's chief economist, said the realtors reporting cancellations, which is higher than the 10% seen in a typical month, is due, at least in part, to shaky consumer confidence.

The U.S. added very few new jobs in June, and the ongoing battle over the debt ceiling has hurt consumer confidence.

"During the debt ceiling discussion there have been pronouncements from major politicians that we could be facing a catastrophe or a collapse," Mr. Yun said. "Anytime those kinds of dire words are used, someone who wants to make a major purchase is going to pause."

Tight credit and low appraisals also may have factored into the uptick in cancellations, but since both factors have existed for months it is unlikely they are the driving force behind the June increases, Mr. Yun said.

Economists say it will take large-scale job growth to persuade families to move out of rentals. "With the unemployment rate still very high and rising, a major recovery is not in the cards," Mr. Dales said.

Interactives
Georgia Country Estate; Built and designed by country music legend Kenny Rogers, this 973-acre estate features a movie theater, six guesthouses and an 18-hole golf course. --Wesley Lowery, 07/20/11
377 words
20 July 2011
The Wall Street Journal Online
WSJO
English
Copyright 2011 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

In 2003, Wes and Liz Adams purchased this Georgia estate, known as Beaver Dam Farms, for $10.25 million from Kenny Rogers, according to property records (press reports have quoted a higher sale amount of about $12.3 million). Mr. Rogers is the country music singer and songwriter whose albums include "The Gambler." A representative for Mr. Rogers did not return a call for comment.

The estate has a 12,000-square-foot main house in addition to six guesthouses, and a golf clubhouse, which contains a lounge, eating area and pro shop. Pictured here is the main house.

Mrs. Adams says the property was a vacation home that they only used a few weeks out of the year, although they hosted their daughter's wedding there.

Mrs. Adams says she decided to sell the property, which is outside of Athens, Ga., after her husband died in February. "Our family just doesn't use the property to its full potential."

In 2005, the Adamses turned the estate into a resort, also named Beaver Dam Farms. Mrs. Adams will entertain buyers looking to use the estate as a resort as well as those who plan to use it as a secondary or primary residence.

The estate has a six-bedroom guesthouse, a four-bedroom guesthouse, and four one-bedroom villas.

Most of the estate's current furnishings were chosen by Mr. Rogers, Mrs. Adams says. The property's amenities are included in the asking price.

Other than some structural improvements, the current owners have left the estate largely unchanged.

The centerpiece of the state is a private, 6,285-yard, 18-hole golf course.

The course has been played by professional golfers during visits to the estate.

The estate also includes a clubhouse, a 90,000-square-feet equestrian and multi-use facility, two barns, a lake house, two swimming pools, clay tennis courts, a spa, conference center, various outdoor entertaining venues and three fish-stocked lakes.

The asking price is $20 million. It is being marketed privately through a Beaver Dam Farms website.

Real Estate
WestLB Seeks Buyer for Hotel, Resort Loans
By Craig Karmin
437 words
20 July 2011
The Wall Street Journal Online
WSJO
English
Copyright 2011 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

Troubled German bank WestLB AG is marketing a portfolio of loans backed by a diverse collection of hotels and resorts that include a ski lodge in Utah, a boutique hotel in lower Manhattan and a beach resort in Miami, according to the offering memorandum.

But this diversity might make it tough to sell the portfolio, which comprises 10 loans with a face value of about $342 million as well as two small properties that the bank owns. Some analysts suggested that the portfolio might attract bids of 60 to 70 cents on the dollar.

"The mix of hotels may make it harder to find one buyer who wants the whole portfolio," said Tom McConnell, senior managing director of global hospitality at broker Cushman & Wakefield. But the Ger\man state that owns much of the bank may be looking to sell the loans quickly through a package, rather than trying to break them up, he added.

WestLB was among a number of European banks that began lending aggressively to U.S. developers during the final years of the property market boom. Many of these loans went sour and contributed to financial stress at these banks. WestLB nearly collapsed during the financial crisis and is owned by the German state of North Rhine-Westphalia and regional savings banks. The Düsseldorf bank is negotiating a break-up plan with the European Union.

John Fox, a hotel analyst at Colliers PKF Consulting, said WestLB's lending may seem more risky because, unlike some foreign lenders, the German bank provided financing for more speculative resort projects

"Some of the overseas banks got into markets they didn't know as well as the urban markets," he said.

A spokeswoman for WestLB declined to comment. A hotel broker at Jones Lang LaSalle, the firm running the sale, also declined to comment.

While the loan portfolio includes the boutique Ace Hotel in Manhattan and the 285-room Loews Hotel New Orleans, it is also stocked with loans to a Cabo San Lucas resort and a luxury spa in the Utah desert.

The offering memorandum categorizes six of the 10 loans as performing. Some of these are part of a lending syndicate, which would make it harder for a new debtholder to gain control of the property.

The Mexico and St. John hotels could discourage many buyers who don't want or can't own overseas properties, and the complexity of some of the non-performing loans could make the portfolio less attractive to many real-estate investment trusts, some hotel analysts said.

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
