U.S. News --- THE OUTLOOK: China Risks Being Next Property-Bubble Blow Up
By Bob Davis
766 words
27 June 2011
The Wall Street Journal
J
A2
English
Copyright 2011 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

BEIJING -- A recent decline in Chinese real-estate prices is starting to shake confidence in the country's economic vitality and open a debate about whether the country's economy is over-leveraged. That's what made the real-estate bubble's aftermath so painful for the U.S. and Japan.

Just two months ago, China expert Nicholas Lardy dismissed concerns about what he labeled a "so-called property bubble" during a conference at the Peterson Institute for International Economics in Washington.

Now, he says a housing downturn could produce a "major, major economic correction" in China.

What changed? A growing realization that much of China's massive stimulus spending and lending of 2009 and 2010 ended up in land purchases, driving up prices in an unsustainable fashion. And a recognition that the Chinese economic system routinely produces bubbles and is unlikely to change any time soon.

The government keeps bank deposit rates well below the rate of inflation to benefit state-owned banks and other firms, which have the political power to defend the status quo. With few financial alternatives to beat inflation, Chinese savers buy real estate, even if supply soars ahead of demand.

During the next three to five years, says UBS economist Wang Tao, prices are bound to head sharply upward again because of the paucity of alternative investments for Chinese savers and the reliance of local governments on land sales for revenue. At some point, she figures, the boom could give way to a bust.

Mr. Lardy expects the cycle to play out more quickly. A number of events could trigger a big selloff, including a sharp rise in interest rates.

Estimates of how badly the economy could be damaged by a real-estate slump reflect different views of the structure of the Chinese economy.

The strength of the real-estate market directly affects the construction, steel, concrete, power and appliance industries. In all, about 50% of China's GDP is linked to the fate of its real-estate market, says Standard Chartered economist Stephen Green.

Mr. Green said a downturn wouldn't be as devastating as the burst bubbles in the U.S. and Japan. In those cases, falling real-estate prices caused bad debt to mushroom and cripple the banking industry.

However, in China, far fewer consumers use debt to buy homes.

Other analysts say there are many more leveraged purchases of real estate than recognized in the official statistics.

To fight the global downturn, Chinese state-owned banks loaned about $3 trillion mostly to giant state-owned enterprises. The money was reported to have largely financed infrastructure projects.

But many of the loans wound up financing real-estate purchases instead, said Deng Yongheng, director of the Institute of Real Estate Studies at the National University of Singapore.

Prices at auctions for residential land in eight major cities doubled in 2009 largely because of highly leveraged purchases by state-owned companies, he and three co-authors calculate. In March 2010, state-owned companies bid up the price of one piece of Beijing land to 10 times the asking price, according to one analyst.

The magnitude of the leveraged purchases is hard to gauge. One indication: Shortly after the Beijing land sale, the Chinese agency that oversees state-owned companies, ordered 78 firms -- whose charters had nothing to do with real estate -- to cease buying and selling property. Nearly a year later, in February 2011, state-owned Xinhua news agency reported that just 14 firms had left the business and another 20 were expected to get out later in the year.

A spokesman for the agency said that the firms needed time to finish their projects.

Over the past year, Beijing has put in place measures to temper real-estate sales, including raising the minimum downpayment for mortgages on second homes to 60% and enacting China's first property tax.

But few expect the anti-bubble measures to last, given concern by the government and Communist Party about sustaining growth, which they see as a key to social stability.

Charlene Chu, a Fitch Ratings Service analyst in Beijing, said state-owned firms have taken on heavy real-estate debt. Thus a sharp fall in prices would produce a raft of nonperforming loans and "would have an outsized impact on Chinese banks."

In other words, a real-estate collapse could lead to a banking crisis -- the kind of woes that have undermined the U.S. and Japan.

License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service[http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=wjco20110627000113]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document J000000020110627e76r0002r


Condo Complex Sparks a Battle
By Laura Kusisto
844 words
27 June 2011
The Wall Street Journal
J
A19
English
(Copyright (c) 2011, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

The sale of a large West Village apartment building sparked a lawsuit by a spurned bidder, highlighting the intensifying competition among investors for prime Manhattan residential properties.

A venture including Belvedere Capital Real Estate Partners and Angelo Gordon & Co. is paying about $70 million for the Printing House at 421 Hudson St., beating out more than 25 potential buyers. The building, which once housed printers, was converted to condominiums 30 years ago. But 105 of the units are operated as rentals.

The deal raised the ire of another big-name investment firm, Taconic Investment Partners. Taconic, which was a finalist in the bidding, has filed a lawsuit in New York state court against the seller, Mountbatten Equities, alleging that the firm "cynically and duplicitously" used Taconic as a "stalking horse" bidder to increase the sale price.

Mountbatten's "failure to negotiate in good faith was the only impediment to consummating the transaction" with Taconic, the firm's complaint states. The complaint asks the seller for $4.4 million in damages.

Alan Gordon, a lawyer representing Mountbatten, denied the seller did anything wrong. He said that Mountbatten negotiated in good faith with Taconic and simply took a more attractive late offer.

"Taconic was the principal party and remained the principal party until the very end. There was never any intention on behalf of the partnership that owns 421 Hudson Street to exploit them in any fashion," Mr. Gordon said in an interview.

Lawsuits of this type aren't unusual in a rising market. According to Taconic's court papers, the firm agreed to pay $77.25 million for the units, which appears to be more than the winning bidder's offer.

But Mountbatten chose the Belvedere-Angelo Gordon group because, under its bid, Mountbatten will retain an undisclosed share in the property's future profits and a role in managing the property.

While most the country's housing market is languishing, Manhattan residential property is hot among investors looking for opportunities to upgrade apartments.

In the case of the Printing House, the Belvedere and Angelo Gordon venture, which also includes apartment developer Myles Horn of MJH Birchwood, is planning to vacate the rental units, renovate them and sell them as condos.

Angelo Gordon, Belvedere and Taconic have all been active players as the New York real estate market has recovered from the downturn. Taconic is best known for its upgrade of 111 Eighth Ave., the enormous office building 15 blocks to the north of the Printing House that Google Inc. acquired late last year for $1.9 billion.

Belvedere and Angelo Gordon, meantime, played a major role in the redevelopment of the Chelsea Market as a specialty-food destination and media Mecca.

Mountbatten, which is owned by Winthrop Chamberlin and Barnet Liberman, bought the turn-of-the-last-century industrial building across from James J. Walker Park in 1975 for about $550,000. It was one of the first commercial-to-residential conversions in the city.

Seeing the residential market heat up in late 2010, Mountbatten put the property on the market through Grubb & Ellis Co.

According to Taconic's complaint, the firm began talks with Mountbatten in November 2010 and the parties exchanged drafts of the contract and "toasted to closing the deal together" in December. Taconic agreed to pay $77.25 million for the units, the documents say, and the deal was set to close at the end of January.

But the sellers delayed the deal, according to Taconic's compliant. They said they needed approval from the building's condo board to move forward but when a meeting of the condo board was held in April, Messrs. Liberman and Chamberlin, both members of the board, "refused to participate," the complaint states. Their lawyer said the sellers didn't attend the condo board meeting because of a conflict of interest.

Belvedere and Angelo Gordon executives say they began meeting with Mountbatten about the Printing House in early spring of this year. They said they struck a deal in which the new owners would pay about $70 million but keep Messrs. Chamberlin and Liberman involved as day-to-day managers of the property and profit participants. "We had to move quickly to take the deal," said Glen Siegel, founder of Belvedere, in an interview.

The Printing House will be one of the more significant luxury residential projects since the recession, combining a coveted location, rare architectural features such as 15-foot ceilings in the units and a recently opened 30,000-square-foot Equinox fitness facility.

The developers nonetheless face a huge task transforming the 30-year-old residential conversion into luxury condos. They'll first need to vacate tenants over time and then fix the common areas, including a barren courtyard, renovating and possibly combining some of the individual units, which currently start at 750 square feet for one-bedrooms. They've hired Corcoran Sunshine to market the property and will select an architect shortly.

License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service[http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=wjco20110627000124]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Investor's Calendar
Investor's Calendar
306 words
26 June 2011
The Wall Street Journal Sunday
SNJR
1
English
(Copyright (c) 2011, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

THIS WEEK

-- Goodbye, QE2: The Federal Reserve will wrap up this week its second round of quantitative easing, the $600 billion Treasury-buying program. On Wednesday, the Fed is scheduled to vote on its final plan to regulate debit-card processing fees.

-- Book Sale: Bookseller Borders must choose a potential buyer in its bankruptcy auction by Friday.

-- Economic Indicators: Consumer-spending figures for May are due Monday; the Case-Shiller home-price index for April comes out Tuesday.

-- Earnings Roundup: Nike, General Mills and Monsanto are among those reporting.

LAST WEEK

-- Slowing Down: Fed officials downgraded projections for U.S. economic growth in 2011, to as much as 2.9% from up to 3.3%. The Fed expects an unemployment rate of 7.8% to 8.2% in the final three months of 2012.

-- Stalled Talks: GOP negotiators pulled out of bipartisan congressional deficit-reduction talks, saying only President Obama and House Speaker John Boehner can negotiate a final deal to raise the debt ceiling and cut federal spending.

-- Growth Up: U.S. gross domestic product, a broad measure of goods and services produced, was revised to a 1.9% annual rate for the first quarter, up from 1.8%.

-- Housing Blues: Sales of existing homes dropped 3.8% in May, underscoring the weakness of the spring selling season and the uneven housing recovery.

-- Mixed Results: FedEx reported a 33% profit jump for its fiscal fourth quarter. And the shipping company said it's increasingly bullish about the global economy. Meanwhile, Barnes & Noble reported a $59.4 million loss for the quarter, though it said e-book sales were growing steadily.

Google Probe: The Federal Trade Commission launched an investigation into whether Google has abused its dominance in Web-search advertising.

License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service[http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=sjco20110627000003]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document SNJR000020110627e76q00002


New York
Rent, Tax-Cap Deal Reached
By Eliot Brown and Andrew Grossman
798 words
25 June 2011
The Wall Street Journal Online
WSJO
English
Copyright 2011 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

The state Legislature Friday evening passed a sprawling piece of legislation that extends the city's rent regulations and places a property tax cap on towns and cities outside of New York City.

The catch-all legislation delivers for Democrats the first notable, if modest, expansion of the city's rent regulations since landlord-friendly provisions were put into place nearly two decades ago. At the same time, the bill, made public just a few hours before a vote, follows through on Republicans promises of a tax cap.

It also contained the extension of an expired tax break for residential developers that had long been pushed by the real estate industry. Further, the bill's text contained an unexpected extension—pushed by the real estate industry—of a tax break for stalled residential developments projects that were slated to lose some benefits.

The omnibus nature of the legislation was by design: Assembly Democrats had pushed to tie up Republican-favored issues such as the tax cap and the real estate tax break in an attempt to gain leverage in negotiations on the rent laws. In the end, neither advocates of more expansive rent regulations nor real estate executives won what they had been hoping, as the final legislation followed the bounds of a compromise outline pushed by Mr. Cuomo.

The four-year rent regulation bill would slow the pace of deregulation by increasing the minimum monthly rent under which a landlord can convert a rent-stabilized apartment to market rates. That monthly rent is moved to $2,500, from $2,000. While the increase received resistance from landlords, they successfully pushed to keep it as a flat rate, not tied to inflation.

Also on Friday, the Assembly unanimously passed a bill designed to make it harder for the Legislature and governor to use money meant for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to fill budget holes.

As they've scrambled to find ways to balance the budget in recent years, lawmakers and the governor have sometimes diverted receipts from taxes that are supposed to be dedicated to paying for the MTA.

The legislation, which the Senate also passed unanimously earlier in the week, seeks to curb that practice by prohibiting the governor from diverting funds and requiring the legislature to make public what the impact on service will be if it does the same.

Mass-transit advocates including the MTA's biggest union, pushed for the bill's passage, dubbing it a "lockbox" for MTA funds. But the lock isn't particularly strong since the Legislature can change the law when it passes budget bills. Nearly all of the diversions from the MTA's dedicated funds were done with legislation, not by the governor acting alone.

Mr. Cuomo hasn't indicated whether he'll sign the bill, but its unanimous passage in both houses of the Legislature makes it appear unlikely that a veto could be sustained.

Also Friday, the Senate passed a bill allowing New York City to let as many as 30,000 livery cabs pick up passengers who hail them on the street everywhere except Manhattan south of Harlem and at the airports. The bill's passage is a win for Mayor Michael Bloomberg, who proposed the plan to improve taxi service outside Manhattan in January. Mr. Bloomberg's Taxi and Limousine Commissioner, David Yassky, has negotiated for months with different parts of the fractious industry to try to find a compromise before settling on the current version last weekend. The Assembly passed the plan earlier this week.

The bill was vigorously opposed by owners of the city's 13,000 yellow taxi medallion, who see the plan as an erosion of their exclusive right to pick up passengers who hail them on the street—a privilege that now costs nearly $1 million per taxi. But city data show that those cabs almost never pick up outside of Manhattan and at the airports. The group that represents the city's yellow-taxi fleet owners said it would upend the industry and threatened to sue if Mr. Cuomo signs the bill into law. He hasn't indicated whether or not he will.

If Mr. Cuomo signs the bill, livery drivers will be able to buy the right to pick up passengers who hail them on the street for $1,500.

They'll have to put credit card readers and meters in their cars and charge the same 50-cent-per-ride tax for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority that yellow cabs must charge. The bill would also let the city sell 1,500 new yellow taxi medallions.

Write to Eliot Brown at eliot.brown@wsj.com[mailto:eliot.brown@wsj.com] and Andrew Grossman at andrew.grossman@wsj.com[mailto:andrew.grossman@wsj.com]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document WSJO000020110625e76p00209


World News: Canada's Housing-Boom War
By Jon Hilsenrath and Nirmala Menon
722 words
25 June 2011
The Wall Street Journal
J
A10
English
(Copyright (c) 2011, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

OTTAWA -- Mark Carney, governor of the Bank of Canada, has chosen his weapons in a battle against a problem all too familiar to many Americans -- a housing boom marked by rising debt and frothy real-estate prices in some markets.

Mr. Carney, like central bankers in other places fighting real-estate booms, is leaning on tougher regulations for banks and home buyers, rather than on higher interest rates, to prevent Canada's rising housing prices from going too far.

"You don't turn to monetary policy first," Mr. Carney said in an exclusive interview with The Wall Street Journal. "The principle is that there are other tools that are the best tools to address the risk of excesses developing in housing, and they should be deployed first. In Canada, we have deployed those other tools. As a consequence, we expect moderation in housing activity."

The Canadian Real Estate Association estimates the national average price of homes sold in May was 376,817 Canadian dollars, or about US$384,510, up 8.6% year-to-year. That is being pushed up in part by historically high sales prices in exclusive Vancouver neighborhoods, and broad-based gains in Toronto. But prices excluding Vancouver were still up 5.6% year-to-year.

The average home price in Vancouver in May, meanwhile, was C$831,555, which was a 25.7% jump from May 2010. In Toronto, prices were up 8.7% to C$446,593.

Mr. Carney has been trying to draw attention to excesses building up in housing, a trend that has emerged in Canada just four years after a historic housing bust in the U.S. In a speech in Vancouver earlier this month, the central banker called the city an "extreme example" of potential problems building elsewhere in the country.

Central bankers world-wide have been debating for years how to respond to the threat posed by potential asset bubbles. Before the U.S. housing bust, many Federal Reserve officials felt the central bank shouldn't try to address bubbles. Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke has acknowledged that the Fed failed to adequately regulate banks during the housing boom.

Some economists also blame the Fed for failing to push interest rates higher in the last decade to slow the run-up in building and residential real-estate prices.

In many other markets today -- including China, Hong Kong and Israel -- central banks and bank regulators are turning to regulatory tools to prevent home prices booms from turning into outright bubbles.

"That is a major shift from five years ago," said Martin Barnes, chief economist at Bank Credit Analyst, a Toronto-based research service. "They have at least acknowledged that they can no longer ignore asset bubbles."

Economists still don't agree on whether higher interest rates should also be used to stop bubbles. Many central bankers see them as a last resort.

Mr. Carney said regulatory tools, including tougher mortgage-insurance requirements imposed by Canadian regulators on borrowers and higher capital standards being imposed on banks, were starting to bite. Higher short-term interest rates could be a weapon against excessive housing prices, he said, but are not the first or primary option.

Mr. Carney is in a tricky spot. Even as home prices rise in Canada, the country has been buffeted by what the central bank chief described as "considerable head winds" from abroad, including a slowdown in U.S. economic growth and a strong Canadian dollar, which is hurting exports.

That could mean that interest rates will stay low for a while longer. Last year, the central bank increased the benchmark overnight interest rate to 1% from 0.25%. Mr. Carney has warned that rates won't remain this low forever. But he suggested he isn't in a rush to raise them.

"In an environment of substantial head winds," Mr. Carney said, "monetary policy may still need to be stimulative in order to close the output gap and in order to get inflation back to target."

The central bank will update its economic forecasts in its quarterly monetary policy report next month. It has been projecting that by mid-2012 the Canadian economy will be back to its full capacity.

License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service[http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=wjco20110625000098]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document J000000020110625e76p0002l


New York
AIG Office Downtown Is Resold
By Laura Kusisto
466 words
24 June 2011
The Wall Street Journal Online
WSJO
English
Copyright 2011 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

(See Corrections & Amplifications item below.)

An investment group has made a profit of about $100 million by reselling the former downtown headquarters of insurer American International Group.

The venture, which included Kumho Investment Bank, of South Korea, had purchased the 66-story tower at 70 Pine St. and 72 Wall St. in 2009 for $150 million. Kumho has now signed a contract to sell 70 Pine to Metro Loft, a developer of luxury rental property, for $205 million.

Metro's principals, Ronny Bruckner and Nathan Berman, say they plan to convert the former AIG headquarters, that was just designated a landmark by the city, to about 1,100 luxury rental units. They hope to begin marketing units by the fall of 2012 and studios will start at around $2,300 a square foot.

"We've been after this building since before AIG was forced to put it on the block," Mr. Berman said in an interview Thursday.

The deal is the latest sign of the sharp rise of some Manhattan properties since the depth of the downturn.

Rental apartment buildings also are hot and other developers are also cashing in on the downtown luxury market. Residential buildings in the area that sat empty through much of the downturn are now finding tenants in many cases, according to brokers.

Kumho originally teamed up in 2009 with Young Woo, a Korean-born investor in New York real estate, and purchased 70 Pine as well as 72 Wall St. from AIG. They paid a total price of $150 million for the two properties.

The Korean venture planned to develop modern office space and condos but never moved forward. Kumho played the lead role in the recent sale. It's not clear how much Mr. Woo is still involved in the property.

The new owners plan to invest substantial money in gut renovating and converting the building.

"For us, this is an area with the highest density in New York, the youngest demographic and an area with the best transportation in New York," said Mr. Berman. "It's also the closest to all of the exciting downtown neighborhoods, like TriBeCa, Meatpacking and the Lower East Side."

The Jones Lang LaSalle team of Richard Baxter, Ron Cohen, Scott Latham and Jon Caplan arranged the deal, but all declined or couldn't be reached for comment. Mr. Woo didn't respond to requests for comment.

Corrections & Amplifications

The buyer of American International Group's former headquarters building at 70 Pine St. plans to convert it into rental apartments, which it will begin marketing at about $2,300 a month for a studio. This article incorrectly said the buyer would be marketing the units at about $2,300 a square foot.

Business
Lennar Profit Slides 65%; Deliveries Tumble, Orders Plateau Amid Lackluster U.S. Housing Market
By Mia Lamar And Dawn Wotapka
351 words
24 June 2011
The Wall Street Journal Online
WSJO
English
Copyright 2011 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

NEW YORK—Lennar Corp.'s fiscal second-quarter profit fell 65% as home deliveries fell and orders came in flat, though the home builder still exceeded expectations.

The housing market has been a trouble spot in the U.S. economic recovery, as high supply and foreclosures have weighed on home prices. Sales of new homes have been particularly sluggish, remaining near record-low levels in April.

However, Lennar has helped itself by looking outside of home building. Its Rialto division, which invests in distressed real estate, has been a driving force behind the Miami-based company's return to profitability. It expects a profitable year.

"Despite operating in a challenging housing market that saw very little evidence of a spring selling season, we were still able to achieve strong results, making this our fifth consecutive quarter of profitability," Chief Executive Stuart Miller said.

For the quarter ended May 31, Lennar reported a profit of $13.8 million, or seven cents a share, down from a $39.7 million, or 21 cents a share, a year ago. The year-earlier period included a six-cent-a-share income-tax benefit.

Revenue fell 6.1% to $764.5 million. Revenue from home sales fell 6.5%, to $648.8 million.

Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters most recently forecast earnings of four cents a share on $646 million in sales.

Gross margin on home sales slipped to 19.4% from 20.6%, making it among the sector's top performers.

Orders were flat from a year ago at 3,204 homes.

New home deliveries fell 7.9% to 2,682 homes, from 2,912 homes last year.

The company's backlog, an indication of future business, edged down 1%, while the cancellation rate was 17%.

Lennar "turned in results about as good as we could expect during this slowing housing environment," Stephen East, an analyst with Ticonderoga Securities, wrote in a client note.

Write to Dawn Wotapka at dawn.wotapka@dowjones.com[mailto:dawn.wotapka@dowjones.com]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

U.S. News: Initial Jobless Claims Tick Up
By Conor Dougherty
511 words
24 June 2011
The Wall Street Journal
J
A5
English
(Copyright (c) 2011, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

The number of people filing new claims for unemployment insurance ticked up last week in the latest sign that the U.S. labor market is sputtering amid slower economic growth.

Initial claims for unemployment insurance increased 9,000 to 429,000 in the week ended June 18, the Labor Department said Thursday.

The four-week moving average of claims, which smooths out weekly gyrations, was 426,250. That was the 11th consecutive week that claims were above the crucial 400,000 mark. Economists generally believe that below that level employers are adding more jobs than they are shedding.

"The labor market continues to crawl along," said Jacob Oubina, an economist at RBC Capital Markets in New York.

The jobless claims, along with other lackluster labor indicators, have convinced many economists -- including Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke -- that U.S. employment growth is stalling. Mr. Bernanke cited weak claims data, among other indicators, in a news conference Wednesday, following the Fed's decision to leave interest rates at essentially zero.

"We project unemployment to come down very painfully slowly," he said.

The initial-claims data measure people filing first-time applications for unemployment insurance. The weekly rise suggests more employers are letting workers go, but also indicates slow hiring, meaning laid-off workers are having a hard time finding new positions without a spell of joblessness.

The most recent claims data were collected the same week that the Labor Department gathers employment information for its monthly snapshot of the U.S. jobs picture, which could presage a glum report to be released early in July. The last monthly report, issued in early June, showed employers added an anemic 54,000 jobs in May, compared with an average of 180,000 a month in the first four months of the year.

Lately, some of the hardest-hit sectors have been state and local government jobs as well as areas that rely on government money. Several states, for instance, reported layoffs in the health-care and social-assistance sector, which has been squeezed by state reductions in Medicaid payments.

U.S. gross domestic product expanded at a 1.8% annual pace in the first quarter of 2011, compared with 3.1% rate in the final three months of 2010. That slowdown almost certainly has continued: Based on disappointing economic data, St. Louis forecasting firm Macroeconomic Advisers predicts 2.0% GDP growth for the second quarter.

Another report Thursday, the Chicago Federal Reserve's National Activity Index, which is an average of 85 economic indicators that aims to predict GDP growth, saw its three-month average decline in May from April, consistent with slowing GDP expansion.

Separately, the Commerce Department said Thursday sales of new homes fell 2.1% in May, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 319,000. The drop followed big increases in March and April, yet came in a month typically popular for home buying.

---

Luca Di Leo contributed to this article.

License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service[http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=wjco20110624000135]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document J000000020110624e76o0003f


U.S. News: Home Resales Dropped 3.8% in May
By S. Mitra Kalita
841 words
22 June 2011
The Wall Street Journal Europe
WSJE
8
English
(Copyright (c) 2011, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

PHILADELPHIA -- The housing slump has reined in Americans' once-insatiable appetite for bigger and better homes.

For years, real estate's growth and survival depended on buyers trading up to more-expensive properties. Now, faced with economic uncertainty, tighter lending and the inability to sell existing properties, homeowners are hunkering down, foregoing dreams of dens and great rooms, fourth bedrooms and second staircases.

The trend can be seen in the latest report on sales of existing, or previously owned, homes for May, released Tuesday by the National Association of Realtors. Overall, the report showed that sales of existing homes fell 3.8% in May, underscoring the weakness of the spring selling season and the uneven nature of the housing recovery. The national median existing-home price was $166,500 in May, down 4.6% from May 2010.

But the report also showed that the market is bifurcating. Sales of homes under $100,000 were up 6.7% nationwide in May, compared with a year earlier, led by a 58% gain in the West. Meanwhile, sales of homes priced between $100,00 and $500,000 -- which represents the vast middle tier of the market -- declined nearly 19%.

The middle tier of the housing market has been more troubled because homeowners in that category are often burdened with more debt and are deeper underwater on their mortgages than people on the bottom or the top of the economic ladder. "What negative equity has done to the market is to gum up the conveyor belt that has worked pretty well," said Stan Humphries, chief economist for real estate portal Zillow.com. "People can't move up a rung because they can't get out, or they don't want to."

To be sure, the squeeze on the middle market varies by region. Sales volume for homes priced between $500,000 and $750,000 in the Midwest posted a 1% increase in May, compared with a year earlier, for example. Median prices in Houston, Miami, San Antonio and Washington, D.C., were all up in May, compared with a year ago.

In many ways, Philadelphia exemplifies the broader demographic shifts affecting real estate nationwide. Baby boomers are downsizing, often selling homes in the suburbs to move back into cities. Price declines in the suburbs have been steeper than in the city. Multimillion-dollar luxury properties, meanwhile, appear more insulated and continue their rise. Sellers who price aggressively tend to find buyers much faster.

But not all are willing. In Bucks County, Pa., Vijay Raju's five-bedroom, five-bathroom home has lingered on the market for 18 months. He listed it for $849,900 -- a price he wouldn't budge on because he put so much work into the property. He said he knows the price is high, but "I didn't want to lose money." by selling at a loss.

About four miles away, Joanna Kot's four-bedroom, two-bathroom on a block of Cape Cod homes sold within two weeks. With an eye on moving into a newer, bigger house, Ms. Kot priced aggressively -- at $199,000. "We put the price down a little because we were worried we wouldn't be able to sell," she said.

The route between Mr. Raju's house and Ms. Kot's winds past at least 10 others for sale, reflecting the county's 11-month supply of homes, according to one real-estate agent.

The high end is largely exempt from the vagaries of the market. For one, it represents a small fraction of sales, and purchasers tend to be all-cash buyers. In Philadelphia, the sale of a 4,250-square-foot penthouse hit a record last year when it sold for $12.5 million. Among the building's host of luxury amenities, 1706 Rittenhouse Square boasts an automated "parking system the Jetsons would love," according to a recent headline in the Philadelphia Business Journal.

"Our projects are aimed at the tiny top sliver of the market," says developer Tom Scannapieco. "The people in this price range are not feeling the pain of this economic slowdown."

But the trade-up buyers -- families that once might have bought a bigger home -- are staying put and trying to do make do with what they have. Luke Chechla, a partner with KLM Contractors, describes clients as "very careful."

"Years ago, they would not only move but improve the quality of the home right away," he said. "Five years ago, if someone had a small leak in the roof, it was, 'How much for a new roof?' Now it's 'Can you fix this without replacing the whole roof?"'

In a sign of the times, Mr. Chechla has begun working with a European supplier of moveable walls. He reasons that if people can't buy a house with more rooms, they can at least divide existing space to create them.

---

Matthew Strozier contributed to this article.

License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service[http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=weco20110622000031]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document WSJE000020110622e76m0000u


U.S. News: Home Resales Slide 3.8%
By S. Mitra Kalita
683 words
22 June 2011
The Wall Street Journal
J
A2
English
(Copyright (c) 2011, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

PHILADELPHIA -- The housing slump has reined in Americans' once-insatiable appetite for bigger and better homes.

The real-estate industry's growth and survival depend on buyers trading up to more-expensive properties. Now, faced with economic uncertainty, tighter lending and a glut of properties, homeowners are hunkering down, forgoing dreams of dens and great rooms, fourth bedrooms and second staircases.

The trend can be seen in the latest report on sales of existing, or previously owned, homes for May, released Tuesday by the National Association of Realtors. Overall, the report showed that sales of existing homes fell 3.8% in May, underscoring the weakness of the spring selling season and the uneven nature of the housing recovery. The national median existing-home price was $166,500 in May, down 4.6% from May 2010.

But the report also showed that the market is bifurcating. Sales of homes under $100,000 were up 6.7% nationwide in May, compared with a year earlier, led by a 58% gain in the West. Meanwhile, sales of homes priced between $100,000 and $500,000 -- which represents the vast middle tier of the market -- declined nearly 19%.

The middle tier of the housing market has seen less activity partly because would-be buyers often cannot sell their existing homes or have put buying on hold as prices continue to fall and labor markets remain unstable. Sellers of homes in the middle tier, meanwhile, often won't capitulate because they are deep underwater on their mortgages -- owing more than their homes are worth -- or otherwise burdened with debt.

"What negative equity has done to the market is to gum up the conveyor belt that has worked pretty well," said Stan Humphries, chief economist for real estate portal Zillow.com. "People can't move up a rung because they can't get out, or they don't want to."

To be sure, the squeeze on the middle market varies by region. Sales volume for homes priced between $500,000 and $750,000 in the Midwest posted a 1% increase in May, compared with a year earlier, for example. And while regional activity coast to coast has been weak, some cities are bucking national trends and posting price gains and reporting strong activity. Median prices in Houston, Miami, San Antonio and Washington, D.C., were all up in May, compared with a year ago.

In many ways, Philadelphia exemplifies the broader demographic shifts affecting real estate nationwide. Baby boomers are retrenching, often selling homes in the suburbs to move back into cities. Price declines in the suburbs have been steeper than in the city. Multimillion-dollar luxury properties, meanwhile, appear more insulated and continue their rise.

But not all are willing. In Bucks County, Pa., Vijay Raju's five-bedroom, five-bathroom home has lingered on the market for 18 months. He listed it for $849,900 -- a price he won't budge on because he put so much work into the property. He said he knows the price is high, but "I didn't want to lose money," by selling at a loss, he said.

About four miles away, Joanna Kot's four-bedroom home sold within two weeks. With an eye on moving into a newer, bigger house, Ms. Kot priced aggressively -- at $199,000. "We put the price down a little because we were worried we wouldn't be able to sell," she said.

The high end is largely exempt from vagaries of the market. For one, it represents a small fraction of sales, and purchasers tend to be all-cash buyers. In Philadelphia, the sale of an 8,444-square-foot penthouse at 1706 Rittenhouse Square hit a record last year when it sold for $12.5 million.

"Our projects are aimed at the tiny top sliver of the market," said developer Tom Scannapieco. "The people in this price range are not feeling the pain of this economic slowdown."

---

Matthew Strozier contributed to this article.

License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service[http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=wjco20110622000127]

New York
Former Helmsley Home on the Block
By Craig Karmin
442 words
21 June 2011
The Wall Street Journal Online
WSJO
English
Copyright 2011 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

The grand 40-acre estate in Greenwich, Conn., that once belonged to Leona Helmsley is back on the market for $42.9 million, less than a year after the current owner bought it for $35 million.

The estate's sale last year was one of the most expensive ever in this affluent New York suburb. It created a stir because it was marked down substantially from the Helmsley estate's initial asking price of $125 million.

The property includes a carriage house, walk-in vault and koi pond. While it lacks beachfront access, it has hilltop views of Long Island Sound.

Brokers familiar with the estate say the current owner purchased the property through an attorney, so the person's identity isn't publicly known.

Brokers were taken aback that the property, purchased in October, was already up for sale, and said it was unlikely the owner had moved in.

"This is a big surprise," said Barbara Wells, a sales agent with Prudential Connecticut Realty.

The listing by Jane Basham of David Oglivy & Associates says that the formal rooms have been "restored to the original oak paneling." In an email, Ms. Basham added that work on the bathrooms and kitchens "have brought it to 2011 ideas of taste by removing all earlier incursions on the wonderful original architecture."

The mansion, also known as Dunnellen Hall, has 28 rooms, including a reception hall with an 86-foot-long gallery, a master suite and a wine cellar with tasting room.

The new listing comes amid signs that the Greenwich market may be gathering some steam after prices fell by about 25% from the market's peak, Ms. Wells said.

Brokers also are watching another big listing: 84-80 Field Point Circle on the Greenwich waterfront.

Earlier this month, the century-old estate—with an indoor and outdoor pool, a 35-foot-tall atrium and its own suspension bridge—went into contract. The asking price was $42.5 million, listed by Joseph Barbieri of Sotheby's International Realty.

Leona and her husband Harry B. Helmsley bought their property for $11 million in 1983 and spent $8 million on renovations, including a $1 million dance floor.

The property played a key part in Ms. Helmsley's federal tax-evasion conviction.

In 1989, the Helmsleys were accused of illegally billing their company for more than $3 million in renovations to the Greenwich estate. Ms. Helmsley was convicted and sentenced to 16 years in prison, though she served less than two. She died in August 2007.

Write to Craig Karmin at craig.karmin@wsj.com[mailto:craig.karmin@wsj.com]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document WSJO000020110621e76l0018h


New York
Sale of New Rochelle Site Revives Development Talks
By Dawn Wotapka
610 words
20 June 2011
The Wall Street Journal Online
WSJO
English
Copyright 2011 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

Efforts to revive New Rochelle's downtown have gotten a boost from the sale of a blighted former movie theater to a buyer who plans to rehabilitate the eyesore and, possibly, build an apartment building on the site.

A venture of ABS Partners Real Estate LLC and Brause Realty Inc. has paid about $2.6 million for the 53,000-square-foot building at 587-599 Main St. that in its heyday was a Loews movie theater but later became the Palladium nightclub. For now, the new owners plan to upgrade the property and rent it to small retail and office tenants.

But when the economy gets stronger, the venture may revive a plan to develop apartments on the site, says Jason Fein, associate managing partner with Manhattan-based ABS. "It might be a short wait, it might be a longer wait," he says.

New Rochelle has shown signs of progress as city leaders and businesses have tried to reverse decades of decline. Several major residential projects were built there in recent years, including the Trump Plaza condominiums and multistory rental buildings with more than 1,000 units developed by AvalonBay Communities Inc., one of the nation's largest apartment companies. But the downturn has slowed New Rochelle's effort to restore itself as a bustling transit-oriented hub. An earlier plan to develop housing at the Loews site was shelved. Because of slow sales, some Trump Plaza units are offered on a rent-to-own basis.

The theater site mirrors the tale of many early American suburbs. New Rochelle, mostly known as a bedroom community serving New York, saw tremendous growth and success during the first half of the 20th century, says Mayor Noam Bramson. Back then, the Loews theater was part of a flourishing downtown benefitting from its affluent residents and proximity to the city.

But the city "went through a 50-year stretch of very significant economic challenges," Mr. Bramson says. Americans nationwide began abandoning their picturesque urban cores in favor of suburban neighborhoods and shopping malls. The New Rochelle area slipped into a downward spiral that bottomed out in the early 1990s, Mr. Bramson says. The city lost its Bloomingdale's department store in the 1970s. The theater, made obsolete by larger facilities with multiple screens, was also shuttered.

The shell later housed the Palladium night club, which closed in 2003, because of problems with drugs and underage drinking. "The streets were just out of control," recalls Ralph DiBart, executive director of New Rochelle's Downtown Business Improvement District.

During the housing boom, the .77-acre site was under to contract to be sold to White Plains-based M Squared Development, which had earned approval to build more than 150 residences— both condos and rentals were considered—a three-level parking deck and retail space. But the housing market crashed before construction started and M Squared abandoned the deal. "It was a project where everything was going for it except the final timing," Mr. DiBart says.

Andrew Buzzi Jr., the attorney representing the property's seller G & G Properties LLC , says the men who have owned the site since the late 1980s are retiring. "Their kids have grown up, they've gone on to their own professions," he says.

The property was auctioned and the deal closed last month. Auctioneer Oren Klein with Tranzon Integrated Property Group says the existence of a former redevelopment plan helped the site command a higher price. "We definitely looked at it as a development opportunity," Mr. Fein said. "We like what we see in New Rochelle."

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document WSJO000020110620e76k001md


U.S. News: Unemployment Claims Fall But Job Market Stays Weak
By Alan Zibel and Luca Di Leo
496 words
17 June 2011
The Wall Street Journal
J
A4
English
(Copyright (c) 2011, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

Fewer unemployed Americans filed for jobless benefits last week, but claims remained at an elevated level, pointing to persistent weakness in the labor market.

The recovery has been held back by slow job growth and modest improvement in important economic sectors, such as housing.

New U.S. home construction rose slightly in May, but the long-troubled sector remains sluggish, a separate report showed.

Initial jobless claims dropped 16,000 to a seasonally adjusted 414,000 in the week ended June 11, the Labor Department said in its report Thursday. They continued to hover above the key 400,000 level they have been at since early April.

Economists tend to agree that when claims fall below that level, employers are adding more jobs than they are shedding.

The four-week moving average of new claims, considered a more reliable indicator because it smooths out volatile weekly data, remained unchanged from last week's 424,750 level.

Data indicates that the economic recovery that started in mid-2009 is losing steam.

The manufacturing sector, once the driver of the recovery, stumbled in May as companies ratcheted back production and hiring. A persistent slowdown in hiring represents the biggest threat to the U.S. economy, the latest Wall Street Journal forecasting survey of economists found.

Modest improvement in the housing sector, meanwhile, continues to hinder growth. Construction of homes and apartments last month increased 3.5% from a month earlier to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 560,000, the Commerce Department said Thursday.

Compared with the same month a year earlier, overall new-home construction in May was down 3.4%.

Single-family home starts, which made up about two-thirds of new home construction, rose by 3.7% from the level a month earlier.

Construction of multifamily homes containing at least two units, a volatile part of the market, was up 2.9% on a monthly basis.

"While the increase is encouraging, starts remain at extremely depressed levels and any recovery will be long and arduous," Wells Fargo Securities analysts wrote in a note to clients.

Though the overall economy grew at an annualized rate of 1.8% during the first three months of 2011, the battered housing sector weighed on growth.

Builders have been idled by weak demand from buyers, many of whom are nervous as home prices have fallen to the lowest point of the five-year housing bust.

Buyers have been choosing foreclosures and other previously owned homes rather than new homes, which typically are more expensive.

Reflecting weak demand, the number of homes under construction in May was at the lowest level on records dating back to 1970.

Newly issued building permits, a gauge of future construction, increased 8.7% from a month earlier to an annual rate of 612,000, the highest level since December.

License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service[http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=wjco20110617000149]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document J000000020110617e76h0003t


Business
Unemployment Claims Fall but Job Market Stays Weak
By Alan Zibel And Luca Di Leo
495 words
17 June 2011
The Wall Street Journal Online
WSJO
English
Copyright 2011 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

Fewer unemployed Americans filed for jobless benefits last week but claims remained at an elevated level, pointing to persistent weakness in the labor market.

The recovery has been held back by slow job growth and modest improvement in important economic sectors such as housing.

New U.S. home construction rose slightly in May but the long-troubled sector remains sluggish, a separate report showed.

Initial jobless claims dropped 16,000 to a seasonally adjusted 414,000 in the week ended June 11, the Labor Department said in its report Thursday. They continued to hover above the key 400,000 level they have been at since early April.

Economists tend to agree that when claims fall below that level, employers are adding more jobs than they are shedding.

The four-week moving average of new claims, considered a more reliable indicator because it smooths out volatile weekly data, remained unchanged from last week's 424,750 level.

The economic recovery that started in mid-2009 is losing steam.

The manufacturing sector, once the driver of the recovery, stumbled in May as companies cut back on production and hiring. A persistent slowdown in hiring is the biggest threat to the U.S. economy, the latest Wall Street Journal forecasting survey of economists found.

Modest improvement in the housing sector, meanwhile, continues to hinder growth. Construction of homes and apartments last month increased 3.5% from a month earlier to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 560,000, the Commerce Department said Thursday.

Compared with the same month a year earlier, overall new-home construction in May was down 3.4%.

Single-family home starts, which made up about two-thirds of new home construction, rose by 3.7% from the level a month earlier.

Construction of multifamily homes with at least two units, a volatile part of the market, was up 2.9% on a monthly basis.

"While the increase is encouraging, starts remain at extremely depressed levels and any recovery will be long and arduous," Wells Fargo Securities analysts wrote in a note to clients.

Though the overall economy grew at an annualized rate of 1.8% during the first three months of 2011, the battered housing sector weighed on growth.

Builders have been idled by weak demand from buyers, many of whom are nervous as home prices have fallen to the lowest point of the five-year housing bust.

Buyers have been choosing foreclosures and other previously owned homes rather than new homes, which typically are more expensive.

Reflecting weak demand, the number of homes under construction in May was at the lowest level on records dating back to 1970.

Newly issued building permits, a gauge of future construction, rose 8.7% from a month earlier to an annual rate of 612,000, the highest level since December.

Write to Luca Di Leo at luca.dileo@dowjones.com[mailto:luca.dileo@dowjones.com]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

U.S. News: U.S. Jobless Claims Fall, But Market Stays Feeble
By Alan Zibel and Luca Di Leo
492 words
17 June 2011
The Wall Street Journal Europe
WSJE
8
English
(Copyright (c) 2011, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

Fewer unemployed Americans filed for jobless benefits last week but claims remained at an elevated level, pointing to persistent weakness in the labor market.

The recovery has been held back by slow job growth and modest improvement in important sectors such as housing. New U.S. home construction rose slightly in May but the long-troubled sector remains sluggish, a separate report showed.

Initial jobless claims dropped 16,000 to a seasonally adjusted 414,000 in the week ended June 11, the Labor Department said in its report Thursday. They continued to hover above the key 400,000 level they have been at since early April. Economists tend to agree that when claims fall below that level, employers are adding more jobs than they are shedding.

The four-week moving average of new claims, considered a more reliable indicator because it smooths out volatile weekly data, remained unchanged from last week's 424,750 level.

The economic recovery that started in mid-2009 is losing steam. The manufacturing sector, once the driver of the recovery, stumbled in May as companies cut back on production and hiring. A persistent slowdown in hiring is the biggest threat to the U.S. economy, the latest Wall Street Journal forecasting survey of economists found.

Modest improvement in the housing sector, meanwhile, continues to hinder growth. Construction of homes and apartments last month increased 3.5% from a month earlier to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 560,000, the Commerce Department said Thursday. Compared with the same month a year earlier, overall new-home construction in May was down 3.4%.

Reflecting weak demand, the number of homes under construction in May was at the lowest level on records dating back to 1970.

Newly issued building permits, a gauge of future construction, rose 8.7% from a month earlier to an annual rate of 612,000, the highest level since December.
