The Property Report
Cantor Aims to Change Game --- Idea for Property Derivatives Pegged to Rents Arises From Surprise Acquisition
By Dana Rubinstein Special To The WSJ
1096 words
25 May 2011
The Wall Street Journal
J
C6
English
(Copyright (c) 2011, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

Howard Lutnick, chief executive of investment-banking firm Cantor Fitzgerald, doesn't just want to join the commercial real-estate game. He wants to change how it is played.

As he moves to finalize the firm's recently announced and surprising purchase of commercial-real-estate brokerage Newmark Knight Frank, Mr. Lutnick is looking for creative ways to combine his traditional business of complicated bond trading with the more prosaic world of square feet.

One of the big ideas he is studying: developing a market in property derivatives pegged to rents in individual buildings as a way for landlords and tenants to hedge against unexpected market volatility.

"You know you can hedge orange juice and you can hedge corn, but real estate you can't?" said Mr. Lutnick in a recent interview. "It doesn't make any sense."

Whether Mr. Lutnick can pull this off, of course, remains to be seen, and there are plenty of Newmark competitors questioning whether it would work. But the idea represents the kind of fresh thinking that Mr. Lutnick plans to introduce into the clubby world of commercial real-estate brokerage.

"I think property derivatives will become a common part of tenants' and landlords' transactions in commercial real estate," Mr. Lutnick said.

It took the commercial-property industry and most brokers at Newmark by surprise late last month, when the firm announced it was going to be acquired by BGC Partners Inc., a Cantor spinoff that also is headed by Mr. Lutnick. Few non-real-estate companies have attempted acquisitions of real-estate service companies or started businesses, and even fewer have succeeded. Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and Morgan Stanley both launched office-leasing brokerage firms in the late 1980s but got out of them after the market cratered.

Also, there are no obvious synergies to the deal, which is set to close later this year. BGC was launched in 2004 as a shop in which traders work the phones to put together complicated bond deals and later added eSpeed Inc., an electronic-trading business. Newmark is a traditional New York-based real-estate company that, since it was founded in 1925, has made the lion's share of its revenue from trading, leasing and managing office buildings.

"I think it's still a little bit of a puzzling move," says Patrick O'Shaughnessy, a research analyst at Raymond James. "It's a substantial departure from BGC's normal course of operations."

But the lack of overlap was one of the things that appealed to Newmark's executives, including Chief Executive Barry Gosin, Chairman Jeff Gural and PresidentJames Kuhn. They had been eager to figure out a source of capital to expand the firm, sensing opportunity in this turbulent time of real-estate consolidation.

But they didn't want to do be acquired or merge with a larger real-estate company that would force scores of layoffs at Newmark, which currently employs about 425 brokers. They also were averse to accepting private-equity money, which typically looks for a relatively short-term return.

The price wasn't disclosed, but a person familiar with the deal says it involved cash and BGC stock and was valued in the $125 million to $200 million range.

"It gives us a strong financial partner to continue to grow," said Mr. Gosin, the Newmark CEO, in an interview.

At the same time, Mr. Lutnick has made a few forays into commercial real estate. In late 2009, at Cantor Fitzgerald, he launched a commercial-mortgage-backed-securities underwriting and trading business. And earlier this year, BGC Partners teamed up with Jones Lang LaSalle's LaSalle Investment Management fund-management unit to launch a property-derivatives business in the U.K.

Mr. Lutnick contends that the commercial-real-estate and bond-trading businesses are a good fit because many of the clients overlap. The financial industry is one of the key users of office space in New York, he noted.

Also, at the end of the day, he said, the job descriptions are fundamentally similar. "In commercial real-estate brokerage, it is a customer service, high-value-relationship-driven business that is very much akin to the brokerage businesses of BGC," Mr. Lutnick said.

Cantor Fitzgerald and Mr. Lutnick are best known from the Sept. 11, 2001, tragedy, when the firm lost 658 employees, more than any other World Trade Center tenant. Since then, Mr. Lutnick has slowly rebuilt the firm while continuing to honor the people who died and to support their families.

During the downturn, Mr. Lutnick's businesses have stayed relatively healthy. Like other niche firms, it has benefitted by the demise of bigger competitors like Bear Stearns and Lehman Brothers. Besides commercial real estate, he has also expanded into other businesses, like Cantor Gaming, which manufactures and operates gambling systems at places like the Cosmopolitan of Las Vegas.

BGC's deal with Newmark comes at a time when the real-estate brokerage business is rebounding from the downturn, which saw an enormous decline in transactions. But even as it is recovering, the industry is going through considerable upheaval. Some of the larger firms, like Grubb & Ellis Co., have been struggling, and smaller firms are finding they need to grow to keep up with the demands of corporate tenants with offices throughout the world.

BGC is still working out the particulars of how the derivatives would work, but Mr. Lutnick predicted that they will be traded as well as used by tenants and landlords to hedge against rent increases and decreases.

"The broker's job would be to match those individuals as counterparties in a transaction," Mr. Lutnick said.

Not everyone is convinced that such derivatives would work. They note, for example, that pricing in the office rental market is more amorphous than, say, the market for Treasury bills, so it would be harder to tie a derivatives contract to it. "I think it will certainly be a tough sell," says Gary Rosenberg, a prominent New York real-estate attorney.

But Mr. Lutnick pointed out that his companies have been pioneers in information technology and that expertise could enable Newmark to pinpoint such metrics as market rents for the purposes of settling derivatives contracts.

Newmark's information division "would have enormous technological backing and financial backing," Mr. Lutnick said. "It will be a complete eye opener to our clients."

License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service[http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=wjco20110525000033]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Real Estate
New Chapter for Schrager
895 words
24 May 2011
21:06
The Wall Street Journal Online
WSJO
English
Copyright 2011 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

Ian Schrager, the famed boutique hotel pioneer, said on Tuesday that he is close to securing deals to develop five hotels under his new brand Public, which rejects much of the hip hotel-design concepts he helped to popularize more than two decades ago as the founder of Morgans Hotel Group Co.

"It's not about being a stylish hotel," he said. "It's really trying to get away from the iconic over-the-top blow-the-customer-away kind of design that people are sick of. It's become a Frankenstein monster and being replicated by companies who don't understand the purpose."

The first hotel he plans to open under the Public brand will be in Chicago in October at the Ambassador East, a hotel Mr. Schrager said he purchased for $25 million with Morgan Stanley two years ago and is renovating at a cost of $35 million. Other deals in the works are two in New York City, one in London and one in Los Angeles, he said.

Mr. Schrager, 64 years old, who first became known for creating the Studio 54 nightclub in the 1970s, opened his first hotel, Morgan's, in 1984, which helped to usher in a popular new category of hotels with generally small rooms and a focus on high-design and very social lobby spaces, as well as restaurants, spas and nightclubs.

For his new venture, he said he drew inspiration primarily from the retail outlets for Apple and Trader Joe's, a supermarket that sells specialty products at a discount.

Drawing on those service-oriented retail trends, he said he is hoping to insert a new stripped-down hotel category called "essential services" into the highly regimented hotel space. Like his earlier boutique concepts, the hotels will feature restaurants, bars and, in some cases, nightclubs, he said.

"What I did before was based on exclusivity, and this is inclusive," he said. "This is for everyone that wants it."

Mr. Schrager is simultaneously developing Public and another unnamed brand that he said will be more luxurious but has been more difficult to develop. He is also continuing a partnership with Marriott International Inc. to develop Edition, Marriott's boutique-style brand. Introduced just before the economic downturn, Edition has been slow to develop, with just two hotels open. Marriott is investing to open additional hotels.

Mr. Schrager said he learned from Marriott executives how to simultaneously develop multiple hotels in order to launch a brand on a larger scale.

"Before I did 12 hotels over 20 years," he said. "Now, I hope to have 10 to 15 over five to seven years."

Alexandra Berzon

Clock Is Ticking For Simon

Mall giant Simon Property Group Inc. has an expensive decision to make within the next 90 days on one of its most lucrative malls.

Australian property company Lend Lease Group has reached a deal to sell its 50% stake in King of Prussia Plaza in King of Prussia, Pa., for a hefty $545 million in cash and assumed debt to a Morgan Stanley fund. Simon, which owns the other 50% of the property with joint-venture partner Kravco Cos., has a 90-day right of first refusal to match the Morgan Stanley offer.

A Simon representative declined to comment. Simon, owner of more than 300 U.S. retail properties, manages King of Prussia Plaza.

King of Prussia Plaza is one of Simon's top-selling malls, with annual sales per square foot of $750. The 2.4 million-square-foot mall is 95% occupied, with shops including Neiman Marcus Group, Macy's, Burberry and an Apple Inc. store.

"I would expect Simon to match the offer," says Ben Yang, an analyst with Keefe Bruyette & Woods. "King of Prussia is a trophy mall, and opportunities to buy trophies don't come along very often."

Kris Hudson

Outlet Center Bubble?

Even as mall owners rush into the outlet-center industry, some are wondering if the business is getting a little frothy.

"It's definitely the flavor of the month," said Stephen Lebovitz, president and chief executive of mall owner CBL & Associates Properties Inc., at the International Council of Shopping Centers' annual leasing conference in Las Vegas on Monday. "Projects will be built, but there will be one in each market. I don't think there will be three in Phoenix or Toronto or anything like that."

CBL and a partner are building an outlet center in Oklahoma City. In recent months, Tanger Factory Outlet Centers Inc. has teamed up with a Canadian partner to start building an outlet center near Toronto. Macerich Co. and Simon Property Group Inc. separately have chosen sites for outlet-center sites in the Phoenix market. And Simon on Monday announced it has added its own Canadian partner to build a center near Toronto.

"We'll probably overbuild them," Greg Maloney, president of brokerage Jones Lang LaSalle's retail division, said at the conference.

There are roughly 214 outlet centers in the U.S., with another 40 on the drawing board, according to ICSC. Taubman Centers Inc. CEO Robert Taubman is among the sector's fans, predicting that he will build five to 10 outlet centers in the next 10 years. "The demand has not yet been satisfied," he said. "Clearly, more supply can be built."

Kris Hudson

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

U.S. News: Sales of New Homes Rise, Remain Weak
By Jeff Bater and Jeffrey Sparshott
414 words
25 May 2011
The Wall Street Journal Europe
WSJE
9
English
(Copyright (c) 2011, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)

New-home sales rose more than expected and the median price climbed in April, but the overall pace remained weak for the battered U.S. sector.

Sales increased 7.3% on a monthly basis to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 323,000 in April, the U.S. Commerce Department said Tuesday.

Economists surveyed by had forecast sales would remain unchanged at an annual rate of 300,000.

Despite the unexpected increase, sales have fallen 23.1% since April 2010, which is when a tax subsidy for first-time home buyers ended.

Sales rose 8.3% in March, revised down from a previously estimated 11.1% increase. The March jump followed a February decline that was blamed on the weather as well as fundamental troubles in the housing sector.

Uncertainty over property prices has made prospective home buyers hesitant to purchase new houses. Lower selling prices weighed down Pulte Homes Inc. in its first quarter, with the builder's revenue falling 21%.

Home construction in April fell sharply, the government reported last week.

Builders face competition from previously owned homes, which cost less, and foreclosures caused by the housing bust and the recession have swamped the market with cheap property.

The median price for an existing home in the U.S. is $163,700, the latest data show. The median price for a new home, on the other hand, was $217,900 in April, Tuesday's report said.

A year earlier, the median price for a new home was $208,300. The increase was encouraging because prices have been sinking for a long time, making consumers reluctant to buy because of a belief prices might recede further.

Unsold homes on the market have kept down prices. Tuesday's data showed April inventories were at a record low. But the time it would take to exhaust the supply of unsold homes on the market was 6.5 months in April, above the baseline of six months that economists consider healthy. The supply in March was 7.2 months, and it had been higher last summer, hitting nine months.

The Commerce report said new-home sales in April rose in all four U.S. regions on a monthly basis. Sales increased 7.7% in the Northeast, 15.1% in the West, 4.9% in the Midwest and 4.3% in the South.

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

WEEKEND JOURNAL
The New Global City --- Russians, Brazilians and Chinese are among the biggest players in today's property market
By Candace Jackson
2783 words
20 May 2011
The Wall Street Journal Asia
AWSJ
W1
English
(c) 2011 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. To see the edition in which this article appeared, click here http://awsj.com.hk/factiva-ns[http://awsj.com.hk/factiva-ns]

This spring, Russian billionaire Yuri Milner paid $100 million for a French chateau-style mansion in Silicon Valley, a deal that set a record for the highest price ever paid for a single-family home in the U.S.

In January, Ukraine's Rinat Akhmetov closed on two of London's most expensive apartments ever for a combined $222.5 million. In Paris, a Gulf princess spent $96.9 million last year for a mansion with an inner courtyard, garden and private chapel on the Left Bank.

Some of the biggest residential real-estate buyers in many cities are emerging from places halfway around the globe. In London, one report finds that 65% of buyers in the luxury market hail from abroad. According to the Miami Association of Realtors, nearly 60% of all sales last year throughout the city were to buyers from foreign countries. About half of the buyers in one new luxury condominium building on Manhattan's tony Fifth Avenue are from overseas.

While foreign purchasers make up about 7% of the U.S. residential real-estate market, their numbers have swelled: According to the National Association of Realtors, 18% of Realtors in the U.S. market reported selling a home to at least one international buyer in 2010, up from 12% in 2009.

The makeup of these buyers is changing too, reflecting changes in the global economic scene. Buyers from Russia have returned, and the numbers are growing from Brazil, where the economy grew 7.5% last year. Australians are buying ski homes in Aspen. In Tampa, Florida, Venezuelan buyers are buying heavily discounted beach condos.

One of the biggest factors in many areas is the emergence of Chinese buyers. As housing costs on China's mainland skyrocket -- raising concerns of a property bubble there -- some monied buyers are heading overseas, moving into markets that look safer and, in comparison, like a bargain too.

In Orange County, California, broker Steve High says Chinese buyers now account for more than half of his showings in tony Newport Coast, up from a very small handful two or three years ago. He says many Chinese buyers seek brand-new homes with more than 10,000 square feet to use either for vacations or as a place for their children to live when they attend college. "We have great big houses here, and they're sitting vacant," he says, "Or we have an 18-year-old kid living in the house by himself."

Amy Williamson, the vice president of sales for Prodigy Network, which markets condo buildings like Trump Soho Hotel Condominium in New York, visited Shanghai last month, meeting with local brokers and potential buyers there. Beverly Hills-based broker Joyce Rey traveled to Beijing in October, arranging a reception at an art gallery where photographs of homes priced between $10 million and $125 million were displayed around the room like artwork. Tim Swannie, the Valbonne, France, director of Home Hunts, says one of his agents is working with two Chinese clients who are looking for vineyards in the $5 million-to-$10 million range in the Bordeaux region.

In the U.S., many foreign buyers are taking advantage of the relatively weak dollar. In March, Pascale Saliou, a 44-year-old from Brittany, France, paid about $600,000 for studio in a building with a contemporary art-filled lobby in Manhattan's Chelsea neighborhood. Ms. Saliou has been visiting the city regularly for more than 20 years and finally decided to buy a New York apartment because of the exchange rate. "We never imagined we could one day do this," she says.

Not all foreign purchasers are shelling out millions (in the U.S., the median price paid for a home by an overseas buyer was under $220,000, according to the National Association of Realtors). Not all are traveling thousands of miles. Canadians are the largest group of foreign buyers in the U.S. today, representing about 23% of foreign buyers, up from about 17.6% in 2009, according to the National Association of Realtors.

Global property buyers gravitate to a handful of highly specific locales: In London, Russians and people from the Middle East flock to central Knightsbridge, where blocks of sleek condos offer top-of-the-line amenities. In New York, newer condos packed with contemporary design attract foreign buyers. Here's a look at some of the top global real-estate markets for foreign buyers.

NEW YORK

Last month, Russian composer Igor Krutoy -- who has recorded more than 100 songs in Russia and collaborated with many of the country's music stars -- made headlines when he and his wife, Olga, purchased a 6,000-square-foot 12th floor condo at the Plaza for $48 million. It was one of the highest prices ever paid for a condo in New York.

According to Jonathan Miller, CEO of appraisal and consulting firm Miller Samuel, foreign buyers make up 15% to 20% of all home sales in Manhattan. They're particularly strong buyers of thoroughly renovated or newly built condos priced at several million dollars or more. Pamela Liebman, president and CEO of New York-based brokerage Corcoran Group, says that in the first quarter of this year, nearly 20% of new condo sales at Corcoran went to foreign buyers. One deal under way includes a group of Asian investors who are buying 13 apartments in a building, each priced between $1.5 million and $2.5 million.

Manhattan has long one of the most popular markets in the world for international buyers. But the makeup of international buyers has shifted. Gone are the investors from Ireland who were snapping up condos amid the economic boom in their homeland, says Mr. Miller. Today, it's buyers from China and Brazil. In the past 18 months, brokers say Russians -- known during the boom years for making large real-estate purchases in opulent trophy buildings -- have returned after sitting on the sidelines during the recession.

International buyers tend to gravitate to certain buildings. Luigi Rosabianca, a real-estate lawyer who works with international buyers, says the Andre Balasz-designed William Beaver House in the Financial District is popular with his Latin American clients. "Certain people are attracted to certain energy and aesthetics," he says. At the Sheffield, a 582-unit condo building at Columbus Circle where 28% of sold units have gone to overseas buyers, sales staff now print marketing materials in Mandarin, French, Spanish and Italian.

At midtown's Setai Fifth Avenue Residences, where apartments are priced from $1.2 million to $15 million, about half of the buyers have been from overseas. Giuseppe Rossi, the executive vice president of Bizzi & Partners Development, who is originally from Italy, notes that many Italians have purchased apartments there. "We're Italian developers so there's a certain appeal to Italian products and the way we built," he says. Brazilian buyers have also made several purchases there, including Brazilian soccer star Kaka, who recently bought three apartments in the building which he plans to combine, says Mr. Rossi. (Kaka didn't respond to requests for comment.)

Giorgio Castro, a 62-year-old Rome-based entrepreneur, says he dreamed of owning a place in Manhattan for decades. Last year, with the euro-dollar exchange rate giving him more than a 40% discount, he finally snagged a $1.3 million one-bedroom condo in a Wall Street building designed by David Rockwell.

"It was a good opportunity to buy something I longed for," says Mr. Castro. "With the money I spent, I could not have bought something equivalent in Rome."

LONDON

According to Liam Bailey, head of residential research at real-estate agent Knight Frank, London's ratio of international to domestic buyers for prime real estate is the highest of any major city in the world -- 64% of buyers of central London homes priced over $8.1 million (GBP 5 million) are foreign, Mr. Bailey says.

The number of nationalities represented has also swelled; 61 nationalities purchased homes in London last year, up from 46 in 2009, with Russian, Chinese, Indian and Middle Eastern buyers seeing the biggest growth, according to Knight Frank.

For many, the U.K.'s steady political environment and stable economy make London a safe haven for wealth. Sterling's decline against the dollar -- around 20% since 2008 -- makes property even more enticing. But currency arbitrage and safe-haven status aside, different nationalities are drawn by different aspects.

For U.S. buyers, it's London's leafy Hampstead Village, according to Marcus Oliver, associate director at real-estate agent Chesterton Humbert's Hampstead office. He said 80% of foreign buyers in Hampstead over the past three months have been from the U.S. "Americans are attracted to the quintessentially 'London village' feel of Hampstead, with its quaint Victorian houses and the rolling Heath. It matches up with the cliched impression of London."

Meanwhile, the status of a pad in central Knightsbridge are luring the newly monied Eastern Europeans and Middle Eastern buyers, says Roarie Scarisbrick of HSBC-owned agent Property Vision. Properties like the Knightsbridge, One Hyde Park and the Lancasters, where residents enjoy 24-hour security and amenities ranging from golf simulators to private movie theaters, are attracting some of the world's wealthiest oligarchs and sheiks.

In neighboring Kensington, with its proximity to museums and coffee shops, the typical buyer is French, Swiss or Italian, says independent search agent Charles McDowell. He recently found a home for 38-year-old Parisian Michelle Dellion, in South Kensington. The five-bedroom townhouse on Mulberry Walk cost $16.3 million (GBP 10 million) and has 5,000 square feet of living space.

Mindful of this tendency to flock together, developers have launched targeted marketing drives. Within the last six months, luxury London developments The Heron, Bramah Chelsea, Wellington House and Neo Bankside have held marketing exhibitions in Singapore and Hong Kong.

-- Tara Loader Wilkinson

PARIS

The Paris real-estate market is booming, driven in part by the high prices foreigners are willing to pay.

In the "Golden Triangle" -- the tony area near the Champs-Elysees -- apartment prices rose 38% in the last year, according to the Paris Notary Chamber. For Paris apartments costing over $2.8 million (2 million euros), three foreigners buy into the market for every one foreign seller, says Charles-Marie Jottras, president of the Daniel Feau network of real-estate agencies.

Mr. Jottras just closed his first deal with a Chinese buyer, an apartment on the luxurious Avenue George V for $14.2 million (10 million euros). The six-bedroom apartment, down the street from the Chinese embassy, features a 2,150-square-foot living room.

A new influx of Chinese buyers is also looking at the 16th arrondissement near the Trocadero Place, where stately buildings appeal to foreign buyers. The Brazilian presence is also growing; Jean-Philippe Roux, manager of luxury real-estate agency John Taylor's new Paris office, says he has nine Brazilians interested in the seventh and eighth arrondissements.

France's neighbors Italy and Britain account for about a third of the international market. These buyers often seek apartments on the Left Bank, in the Saint-Germain neighborhood, as well as in the more bohemian Marais area because of the central location for train stations.

Russian and Middle Eastern buyers tend to concentrate in the "Golden Triangle," where there are the most luxurious hotels and boutiques. A 1960s-era building at 12-18 Avenue Montaigne, near the Louis Vuitton and Chanel stores, is a big draw, as is the recently renovated building at number 51-53 on the opposite side of the street.

-- Christina Passariello

HONG KONG

China's housing boom spilled over to Hong Kong, where property prices have surpassed record highs and are now among the highest in the world. According to property agency Savills, Hong Kong's homes are 52% more expensive than London's, and 111% more than New York's.

In April 2011, a 5,636-square-foot condo at 39 Conduit Rd. in the Mid-Levels district sold for $46.4 million (HK$361 million). Local newspaper Ming Pao reported that it was bought by Shi Yuzhu, Shanghai-based founder of online gaming company Giant Interactive.

Mainland Chinese buyers are more concentrated in the new luxury sector of condos priced over $1.5 million (HK$12 million), like the Cullinan in West Kowloon. In this sector, they represented 28.8% of the deals during the last half of 2010. In the ultra-expensive range -- $25.7 million (HK$200 million) and above -- Joseph Tsang, managing director at Jones Lang Lasalle in Hong Kong, estimates that almost all the transactions involve buyers from China.

Mr. Tsang says Chinese buyers look for luxury finishes, ornate decorations and grand hotel-style lobbies. "They're into glamour and bling," he says. "In order to attract the Chinese buyer [from the mainland], you need to put out the most expensive stuff on display."

In the past, the pricey homes along the southern coast of Hong Kong island were popular among well-heeled expatriate bankers from the U.K., Australia and the U.S. But the influx of Chinese buyers and the resulting spike in prices has even forced some members of this wealthy class out of their traditional stomping grounds.

The city's largest brokers routinely organize bus tours for interested buyers from mainland China to visit new development sites.

Local brokerage firm Midland Realty recently organized three tours during the May 1 weekend, a public holiday. By the end of the weekend, the agency had 10 deals signed, starting at $643,000 (HK$5 million) for new condos. During a tour earlier this year, the agency says some buyers purchased units for $1.3 million (HK$10 million) on their first visit to Hong Kong.

"If you look at the new apartments [in West Kowloon], over 60% are mainland Chinese buyers, but if you count the lights at night, you won't see many. It's sold out, but it's pitch dark," Mr. Tsang says.

-- Jason Chow

MIAMI

In the Greater Miami area, nearly 60% of all sales last year were to buyers from overseas, according to the Miami Association of Realtors. For sales of newly built condos downtown, that figure jumps to 90%, says the group.

Many of the buyers are from Brazil, which experienced an economic growth rate of 7.5% last year. Brazil's currency, the real, has risen about 40% against the U.S. dollar in the last two years.

Property developer and marketer Fortune International focused heavily on Brazil to sell Jade Ocean, a 50-story building the company is marketing with infinity pools, a private movie theater and a children's playroom decorated with Philippe Starck furniture.

Its two-story penthouse loft apartments sold for between $3.5 million and $10 million. Nearly 85% of Jade Ocean's sales have gone to overseas buyers.

Fortune's principal developer Edgardo Defortuna says that last fall, he worked with American Airlines to invite a group of potential buyers and American Airlines contacts to a dinner party at an upscale restaurant in Brasilia. "The Black Eyed Peas were having dinner in the next room," he says.

Russian buyers tend to cluster in northern, beachfront areas. Mr. Defortuna says he's planning a trip to Moscow and St. Petersburg to pitch several of his Miami-area buildings. There, he hopes to throw a dinner party with Donald Trump Jr.

Unlike Americans, who tend to look for single-family homes, overseas buyers favor condos. Italians have been drawn to the Capri South Beach, a condo building with downtown views and its own marina, says broker Nelson Gonzalez. The Icon Brickell, a three-tower complex downtown, has a large number of British and Brazilian owners, says Oliver Ruiz, a managing broker with Fortune International Realty.

Venezuelans are also a growing presence, as are buyers from Italy, Spain and Switzerland. Phillip Yaffa, an owner of the Miami office of Engel & Volkers, says a waterfront home sold last week for $9.4 million to a Swiss buyer.

Henrik Wiingaard-Madsen, a shoe-manufacturing company owner from Denmark, says he got a 30% discount in July for two apartments in the Icon Brickell -- $520,000 for a two-bedroom and $840,000 for a three-bedroom -- plus a rebate. Icon "had so many units, they were kind of desperate at the time," he says.

-- Candace Jackson

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Business
Strains Visible in Homes Data; Number of Borrowers in Foreclosure Remains High While Sales Take Another Hit
By Nick Timiraos And S. Mitra Kalita
680 words
20 May 2011
The Wall Street Journal Online
WSJO
English
Copyright 2011 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

The number of American households behind on mortgage payments hovered at its lowest level in nearly two years during the first quarter, but the number of borrowers in foreclosure stayed near record high levels, the Mortgage Bankers Association said on Thursday.

Separately, sales of previously owned homes declined in April, further underscoring the challenges facing a troubled U.S. housing sector that has limped along since home-buyer tax credits ended last summer.

The MBA reported that 12.8% of mortgage loans on one-to-four-unit homes were 30 days or more delinquent or in the foreclosure process as of March 31, representing more than 6.2 million households. That was down from 14% one year ago and 12.9% at the end of last year.

The number of borrowers that are seriously delinquent—meaning they have missed three or more payments—has now declined for five straight quarters.

"We're looking at a market on the mend. We're not healed yet but things are looking better than they did certainly in the year before," said Jay Brinkmann, the MBA's chief economist.

Still, the report underscored the fragility of those gains. After adjusting for seasonal factors, the report found that the number of newly delinquent loans ticked up slightly in the first quarter.

Meanwhile, the National Association of Realtors reported that existing home sales fell 0.8% in April from March to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.05 million, a sign of a "very sluggish housing recovery," said NAR chief economist Lawrence Yun. The median sales price fell 5% to $163,700 from $172,300 a year earlier.

Inventory of homes for sale climbed at the end of April to 3.87 million. At the current sales pace, it would take 9.2 months to sell those homes, compared to an 8.3-month supply in March. A healthy level would be about six months.

High foreclosure inventories remain one of the biggest threats to a housing recovery, particularly in light of anemic demand. Nearly 2.2 million households are in foreclosure, according to the MBA survey.

"Anyone hoping for a sustained recovery in the housing market is not going to find it," said real estate professor Christopher Mayer of Columbia Business School. Given the heavy volume of foreclosures that tend to sell at discounted prices, "it's hard to predict anything but more declines in prices," he said.

Fannie Mae's chief economist Doug Duncan said rising gas prices and increased costs of loans from the Federal Housing Administration may be weighing on the overall real estate market. "All those small things can make for a significant percentage change," he said. "You just never know how they factor into buyers' perceptions."

Banks initiated fewer repossessions during the first quarter than at any time since the end of 2008, according the MBA data. The nation's largest banks have had to overhaul their foreclosure processes after signs that they were improperly preparing foreclosure paperwork last fall, which has sharply curtailed foreclosures in many states.

The data show how foreclosure inventories remain elevated largely as a result of a handful of states that have struggled to deal with a glut of foreclosures. Florida accounts for 24% of all loans in foreclosure for the country as a whole, and nearly one in seven borrowers in the state are in some stage of foreclosure.

The states with the biggest increases in foreclosure inventories—Florida, New Jersey, and Illinois—require banks to process foreclosures through courts.

California and Arizona have also faced unprecedented levels of soured loans, but foreclosure inventories are down from peak levels. Those states don't require foreclosures to move through the court system.

"You have to think regionally now, not nationally," said Fannie's Mr. Duncan. Judicial backlogs "will affect markets, particularly if they are not seeing strength in employment."

Write to Nick Timiraos at nick.timiraos@wsj.com[mailto:nick.timiraos@wsj.com]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document WSJO000020110520e75k00050


Heard on the Street / Financial Analysis and Commentary
1316 words
19 May 2011
The Wall Street Journal (Europe Edition)
WSJE
32
English
Copyright 2011 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved

Greece Seeks Salvation in Privatization

Could Greece's tragedy yet have a happy ending?

Many investors think the country has little chance of avoiding a default at some point. Its slim hopes of avoiding that depend on an ambitious 50 billion euro ($71 billion) privatization and real-estate development program by 2015, with 12 billion euros to 17 billion euros of receipts now promised by 2013. Wednesday's announcement of a raft of advisers for privatizations ranging from gambling companies to motorways suggests it may finally be serious. Still, execution risk remains high.

Greece has no shortage of assets. It has state-owned enterprises alone valued at 44 billion euros, according to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. These include ports, power, transport, water and gambling companies. In addition, the government owns real estate with an estimated value of 200 billion euros to 300 billion euros, including 2004 Olympics facilities, military property and land used for uncontrolled private development.

But despite commitments given to the International Monetary Fund and European Commission, Greece has been dragging its feet. Unlike the U.K. privatizations in the 1980s, Greece seems likely to have to sell mostly to foreign investors rather than to its own public, heightening the sensitivities. But attitudes are changing: A recent poll showed more than seven in 10 Greeks support privatization. The Socialist government can count on support from the right-wing opposition for asset sales.

The challenge now is to find investors willing to put money into Greece. Spain's Gas Natural has indicated it may bid for a stake in gas company DEPA; Athens International Airport also looks set to draw international interest, though the deal's value will depend on the terms of a new concession agreement.

Hurdles remain. Financial buyers may find it difficult to borrow against Greek assets. And on the real-estate side, progress may be slow. Even now, Greece is only just establishing a single land registry; its banks are cataloguing its real-estate assets; and the country is having to develop surface rights and long-term leaseholds. Conditions for developers remain unclear. Yet Greece is relying on real estate to generate 35 billion euros of the 50 billion euro target. This is hugely ambitious.

Still, the prize is worth it. If it does raise 50 billion euros -- equivalent to 20% of gross domestic product -- Greece's debt-to-GDP would fall to 134% in 2015 from a current forecast of 151%, according to the IMF, and its debt would be on a clear downward trajectory. That estimate excludes other economic benefits, including increased foreign investment elsewhere in the economy, higher productivity and the opportunity to buy back debt at sky-high yields.

What Greece is confronting is nothing less than a Thatcher-style revolution. But the comparison is a reminder that what is promised is achievable -- providing one has a Thatcher.

-- Richard Barley

London Property Scene's Gold Dust

The London property gold rush shows little sign of flagging. Prime office values have soared more than 30% from June 2009's lows and yields average 5.25%, close to precrisis levels. Now Land Securities, the U.K.'s largest real-estate investment trust, says rents are rising, too.

But while London is booming, there is little to cheer elsewhere in the U.K. commercial real-estate market. Investors need to approach the sector with care.

London has had a remarkable run, largely driven by overseas investors looking for relatively liquid, safe-harbor assets.

Rent rises add juice to the story: Land Securities on Wednesday said rents rose 4.7% across its portfolio, helping it deliver a near-20% increase in net asset value in the year ended in March, well ahead of analyst expectations.

That could be just the beginning. Long leases on older office blocks barely modernized since the 1990s are soon to expire, potentially fueling tenant demand at a time when London faces a shortage of new space. The squeeze could boost rents to almost GBP 60, or $97, a square foot by year end from GBP 55 a square foot in the first quarter, forecasts property adviser DTZ.

Outside London, it is a different story: Lower-quality secondary assets are still valued 40% below precrisis levels and may have further to fall.

Lloyds Banking Group and Royal Bank of Scotland Group have almost GBP 70 billion in U.K. commercial real-estate exposure that they need to offload. Ireland's National Asset Management Agency holds a further GBP 10 billion, which it plans to reduce 25% by 2013; other borrowers may try to sell ahead of refinancing deadlines.

With its primary focus on high quality, London real estate, Land Securities is largely insulated against these risks.

Despite an 18% rise this year, the shares still trade at a 4% discount to its March 2011 net asset value. With plans to build 4.4 million square feet of London space to take advantage of rising rents and strong investment demand, that looks cheap.

-- Renee Schultes

Taking Stock Of

China's Growth

Prospects

Worried about Chinese growth? Here is another reason: high inventories mean that if demand weakens, output could fall even faster.

The inventory cycle amplifies manufacturing's ups and downs. When demand is strong, businesses step up output and add to inventories, giving growth an extra boost. When demand falters, producers go slow and reduce inventories, giving growth an extra kick in the teeth.

In the 2008 crisis, the global collapse in demand spurred businesses to cease production and sell down inventories, exacerbating the economic impact. When growth started to get back on track in 2009, restocking gave it an extra boost.

The process is the same in China. But it is even tougher to find good inventories data than in other countries. What information there is points to high levels of inventory that will damp growth if final demand slows in the months ahead.

Data from the China Federation of Logistics and Purchasing show additions to manufacturers' stock of finished goods in March and April, unusual because the data normally point to falls in inventory. Calculations by Wang Tao, an expert on the Chinese economy at UBS, show that in key parts of the industrial sector, the ratio of inventory to sales has returned close to precrisis levels.

The outlook for demand is tough to call. But there are reasons for concern. Growth in industrial value added was 13.4% year-on-year in April, from 14.8% in March. Real-estate investment remains robust, but a drop in construction because of government controls and oversupply is widely expected.

The joker is inflation. If a moderating consumer-price index means an end to tightening monetary policy, growth should bounce back and worries about the inventory cycle recede. But if inflation remains high, and policy tilted toward tightening, high inventories will amplify any slowdown in the months ahead.

-- Tom Orlik

Overheard

The north-south divide couldn't be more stark. As Greece wrestles with slow privatizations and markets bet that some kind of debt restructuring or bond exchange will take place, Swedish debt managers are wrangling with the opposite -- and rather more welcome -- problem. Partly thanks to high privatization receipts, Sweden is forecast to have budget surpluses of 99 billion Swedish kronor ($15.7 billion) in 2011 and 68 billion kronor in 2012. But that means debt issuance is declining sharply. Government debt is forecast to fall to 30% of GDP in 2011 and to 27% in 2012. That makes it difficult to maintain liquidity in benchmark bonds. So the Swedish debt office will be offering a restructuring, of the positive kind, to let investors roll exposure into bonds that mature in 2022. It should have no trouble drumming up demand for that deal.

---

overheard@wsj.com

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Ahead of the Tape
Markets
Real Test for Housing Markets to Come Later
By David Reilly
414 words
19 May 2011
The Wall Street Journal Online
WSJO
English
Copyright 2011 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

Housing markets could sure use some good news.

Existing-home sales out Thursday may provide a modicum of it. Analysts expect data from the National Association of Realtors to show that closed sales of existing homes in April rose about 2% from the prior month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of about 5.2 million units. While that is still down from the 5.8 million pace of April 2010, last year's figures were goosed by the home buyers' tax credit. That incentive did little more than pull sales forward; once it expired, they slumped to a 3.86 million trough in July 2010.

The latest figures should provide a clearer picture of real sales activity. But as positive as that may be, there still isn't much to cheer about.

For starters, pending home sales, which typically lead closings by a month or two, rose 5.1% in March. That would imply that Thursday's figures could show growth of even more than 2%; anything below that consensus number will be particularly disappointing.

The real test comes later this month with the next round of pending-sales figures, for April, showing contract activity in the clutch spring selling season. Economists expect those signings to drop by about 2%, partly due to bad weather. Another potential factor: On April 18, premiums increased for mortgage insurance provided by the Federal Housing Administration. That likely led to higher demand for homes in March and early April, noted economists at IHS Global Insight. "This surge will result in higher closings in April, and possibly also in May, followed by a sharp drop-off," they wrote.

So unless contract signings post a strong rebound in May, it is tough to see how housing will get up off the mat. And this doesn't bode well for prices. If sellers can't unload homes during the spring, they will be more inclined to aggressively cut prices. That, along with the wave of distressed properties still coursing through markets, may mean that any 2011 price drops are more severe than expected.

Falling mortgage rates, which averaged 4.63% last week, may be an offset. But they alone won't counter still-high unemployment. Until that improves markedly, and the huge inventory of unsold homes declines, investors should beware any housing head fakes.

Write to David Reilly at david.reilly@wsj.com[mailto:david.reilly@wsj.com]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document WSJO000020110519e75j000gp


Real Estate
Paving the Way for Electric Cars; Jones Lang LaSalle Seeks Locations to Plug In 2,000 Charging Stations
541 words
18 May 2011
The Wall Street Journal Online
WSJO
English
Copyright 2011 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

Commercial brokerage Jones Lang LaSalle Inc. is helping to pave the way for the emergence of the electric car by scouting various cities and states for 2,000 sites for charging stations.

Ecotality Inc., a San Francisco company overseeing the placement and operation of the stations under a $115 million federal grant plus matching funds hired Jones Lang, which in recent weeks began seeking property owners willing to host a station, mostly in West Coast cities.

The stations, which measure 66 inches high, 20 inches across and 17 inches in depth, typically occupy no more than one parking space.

Targeted will be sites where users would spend at least an hour, allowing their Nissan Leafs or Chevy Volts to draw a full charge. Likely sites include shopping centers, restaurants and municipal offices. Ecotality will install the charging stations at no cost to the property owners.

Kris Hudson

Endeavor's Last Mission

The space shuttle Endeavor, which blasted off for its last space mission on Monday, will have a new job when it returns to Earth: helping in the economic development of southern Los Angeles.

The California Science Center Foundation, located in the disadvantaged area, was chosen last month by NASA as the Endeavor's final resting place. The museum, which opened in 1998, is now beginning work on its third phase, which will have an air and space theme. Its main attraction naturally will be the Endeavor, which first went into space in 1992.

Jeffrey Rudolph, the center's chief executive, on Tuesday said selection of an architect for the 200,000 square foot addition will begin soon. The estimated price tag is about $200 million, and Mr. Rudolph says that if fund raising is successful, he hopes it will open within five years. Southern Los Angeles has seen other signs of improvement in recent years, notably the refurbishment of a public swimming pool that was built for the 1932 Olympics.

Mr. Rudolph attended Monday's blastoff at Cape Canaveral. "It's our Endeavor," he said. "I felt like telling everybody to be careful."

Peter Grant

Creditors Bash Casino Deal

The bankruptcy of Station Casinos Inc., the Las Vegas-based chain of casinos geared toward locals, has turned into a tug of war for one of its prized assets: the Green Valley Ranch Resort.

Station, which had its own bankruptcy plan confirmed by a court last year, placed two dozen subsidiaries into bankruptcy last month, as part of a larger prepackaged plan to acquire Green Valley's assets. Included in those bankruptcy petitions was the 50% stake it already owns of Green Valley.

Green Valley Ranch's creditors are lashing out at Station's plan to take full control of the Henderson, Nev., casino resort, saying they have been deprived of due process in the company's bankruptcy case and reiterating that the results of an auction for the company 12 months ago are "now stale."

In a Monday filing with the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Reno, Nev., Green Valley's official committee of unsecured creditors said the company has "stonewalled" creditors' attempts to properly evaluate the deal.

Joseph Checkler

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document WSJO000020110518e75i000gq


Business
Economic Gains Fail to Revive Housing
By Sara Murray
471 words
18 May 2011
The Wall Street Journal Online
WSJO
English
Copyright 2011 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

New-home construction fell last month as a slowly growing economy has yet to revive the moribund housing market.

Construction of homes and apartments dropped 10.6% in April to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 523,000, compared with a month earlier, the Commerce Department said Tuesday. Home starts are down 23.9% from the same month a year ago, reflecting a market that has struggled as foreclosures drive down prices and builders face financing difficulties.

"It's flat at the bottom," said Patrick Newport, an IHS Global Insight economist. "It's not getting any worse, it's not getting any better."

Single-family home building declined last month, falling 5.1% to an annual rate of 394,000. Construction was down in most of the U.S. last month, falling in the South, Midwest and West. In the Northeast, though, single-family home building rose 12.8%. Compared with the same period last year, new single-family home starts were down 30.4%.

Construction of multifamily housing with at least five units, which tends to be more volatile, plunged 28.3% last month.

Measures of future construction offered little hope of a quick turnaround. Building permits fell 4% to an annual rate of 551,000. Permits for single-family homes dropped 1.8%. Permits for multifamily structures with at least five units declined 13.9%.

Economists predict the housing market is in for a slow recovery. Government incentives, such as the first-time home-buyer tax credit, helped home sales last year. But since its expiration, the housing market has faltered.

Ultimately, it will take stronger income and job growth to inspire more families to purchase homes, working through the inventory that accumulated during the downturn. In the meantime, residential construction is likely to weigh on the economic expansion.

While the housing market sputters, other U.S. industries are recovering. A semiannual survey of purchasing and supply executives in manufacturing and service industries showed both expected higher revenue and increased hiring this year, the Institute for Supply Management said Tuesday.

Manufacturers were more optimistic, as executives predicted revenue would rise 7.5% this year. That's an improvement from their forecast in December, when they expected revenue to increase 5.6%. Hiring is expected to increase 2.9% through the rest of the year.

Service executives expected more subdued growth, forecasting a 2.1% increase in revenue this year, down from their earlier prediction of a 3.4% rise. Employment is expected to rise 0.9% for the rest of 2011.

"Price increases and slow employment growth are prominent areas of concern in the non-manufacturing sector," Anthony Nieves, head of the nonmanufacturing survey committee, said in a release.

Write to Sara Murray at sara.murray@wsj.com[mailto:sara.murray@wsj.com]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document WSJO000020110517e75i00a6t


US
A House Divided: Soap Opera in Cincinnati
By Ellen Byron
1329 words
18 May 2011
The Wall Street Journal Online
WSJO
English
Copyright 2011 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

CINCINNATI—For a place that's been empty for five decades, the grand old home of Ivory soap's inventor, James Norris Gamble, is seeing a lot of action.

The nonprofit group funded by the Gamble family fortune is trying to tear it down. An irregular band of amateur local historians and neighbors is trying to save it. All the while, termites are eating it.

For the past year, the two sides have been warring over the Victorian home—nestled on a 22-acre property here—in the streets, in court, at Cincinnati city council meetings and on Internet discussion boards. The loose-knit group trying to save the property has won some important battles, but a number of appeals are wending their way through county and federal courts. Most of them ultimately could grant the Gamble group, the Greenacres Foundation, a demolition permit. The latest appeals will be heard in county court Wednesday.

"We are dealing with a national treasure," said Gregory Kissel, an ardent Gamble historian who often tops off his full-time work as an architect with 40-hour weeks to save the home, and who helped get it designated a local historic landmark. "There's an intrinsic value to this home that goes beyond just dollars and cents. This is our history."

Defenders of historic homes beyond Cincinnati are watching closely, worried the historic landmark designation could be undermined. "We don't want to set a precedent that these ordinances can be ignored when certain people don't want them to be enforced," said Royce Yeater, the Midwest director for the National Trust for Historic Preservation.

Despite the mounting public pressure, Greenacres is determined to take the home down, arguing that it is in irreversible disrepair and would be too expensive to fix. The foundation, which focuses on conservation and culture, has a net worth of $249 million, according to tax filings.

Greenacres wants to turn the property into an outdoor education center. It plans to rebuild some of the Gamble rooms inside a barn, which is in better condition than the house.

Mr. Gamble was born in Cincinnati in 1836. His father had helped launch Procter & Gamble Co., today the world's biggest consumer-products company. Mr. Gamble joined his father's company as a young man, fascinated by the chemistry behind soap and candle making. In 1879, his experiments with a pure, white floating soap, strong enough to clean laundry but gentle enough for bathing, helped transform P&G from a regional player to a national one.

In recent years, his home, prized by architects for its fixtures, has fallen deeper and deeper into disrepair. The roof leaks, the foundation sags, the paint peels and termites eat through structural beams. The furniture, ornate woodwork and other fixtures have been removed to protect them. Much of this now sits in the property's barn, including Mr. Gamble's eight-nozzle shower.

Neighbors, afraid Greenacres will try to sneak the demolition past them, keep watch over the house. Jan Peak lives next to it and spies on it from the cover of a large oak tree in her backyard, with a city official's number on hand in case she detects any suspicious activity. She is going on high alert this week as the court cases move forward.

"My dogs help, too," Ms. Peak said.

Greenacres is headed by 99-year-old Louise Nippert, one of the wealthiest women in Cincinnati. Ms. Nippert's husband, Louis Nippert, was Mr. Gamble's grandson. The Nipperts founded Greenacres in 1988 and converted their estate and surrounding gardens into a cultural and environmental-education center.

The Gamble House, which is thought to have been constructed in the 1830s or 1840s, stayed in James Norris Gamble's immediate family for about 90 years. When his daughter, the last full-time resident, died in 1961, it passed to Mr. Nippert. His careful care of the property ended with his death in 1992.

The home remained in Ms. Nippert's possession until 2009, when she passed it to Greenacres with the stipulation that it be demolished, according to Carter Randolph, executive vice president of Greenacres. Mr. Randolph said Ms. Nippert, a member of Greenacres' board, declined to comment.

Efforts to save the house began in January of last year, when Bob Prokop, a Web developer and amateur historian, spotted hints of a plan to demolish the property on a site that lists violations of municipal code, including one against the Gamble property for peeling paint and broken sidewalks.

"That was when I sounded the alarm," Mr. Prokop said.

"That's when all hell broke loose," said Mr. Randolph. He sees the battle as a test of individual property rights, a point he underscored by handing a reporter a pocket-size Constitution.

Cincinnati's history buffs banded together. They wrote letters to city officials, worked the courts to block the demolition permit and marched in picket lines carrying bars of Ivory soap. "If you've used Ivory soap, you know Mr. Gamble!" protesters hollered. One sign read: "Greenacres: NOT the Place to Be."

They set up a Facebook group called "Save the Historic Gamble Estate NOW!" and have attracted nearly 3,000 members. "It's like an obsession," Mr. Prokop said.

The house lacked a specific landmark designation until last spring, when city officials unanimously supported zoning it as a local historic landmark. City Councilman Charlie Winburn distributed bars of Ivory soap to fellow members so they could wash themselves clean if they voted the wrong way.

Greenacres has fought the landmark designation, an issue that will come up in county court Wednesday, as it disputes the city's denial of a demolition permit.

Preservationists have tried to buy the home for as much as $250,000, but Greenacres wants $10 million—$2 million for the home and $8 million to endow it—plus a detailed plan for its future use. Mr. Randolph said that the price was based on estimates from preservation experts and that he has dismissed some offers because they were contingent on fund raising.

"We're confident we can raise the funds, but only if we have an agreement with Greenacres in place," said Paul Muller, executive director of the Cincinnati Preservation Association, which has made offers to buy the home.

Procter & Gamble has tried to steer clear of the fight. It said it would consider donating to the Gamble house's preservation, but a spokesman said the company "supports the role that [Greenacres] plays in respecting the wishes of the family that endowed it."

Rather than maintain a grand, walled estate like other corporate giants of the time, Mr. Gamble, an active philanthropist, lived for some 60 years in his relatively simple Victorian home. Advocates for its preservation say if the house had featured more grandiose architecture, they might have had an easier time preserving it.

"He is an extraordinary figure whose modesty and humanity is, ironically, being used to dismiss the importance of his lifelong home when in fact it illustrates it," Mr. Muller said.

The lavish home of Cincinnati's yeast titan is faring much better. Greenacres funded a $7 million overhaul of the Julius Fleischmann estate, turning it into an arts education center and space for corporate events and wedding receptions that opened in 2007.

Mr. Randolph, pointing to the damaged siding of the Gamble house, said the two homes aren't comparable. "Every place you see here you see wood," he said. "At the Fleischmann house you have stone walls. Some of the slate must be close to an inch thick."

In the end, the matter may be resolved by the insects and the elements. Time is not on the home's side. This year a local newspaper ran the headline "At Gamble House, Is It Demolition by Neglect?"

Write to Ellen Byron at ellen.byron@wsj.com[mailto:ellen.byron@wsj.com]

Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Document WSJO000020110517e75i009cj


Asia
Asia's Top Stock Pickers
16672 words
17 May 2011
03:53
The Wall Street Journal Online
WSJO
English
Copyright 2011 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

Here's a list of the top three stock pickers in each sector or country, as ranked by their recommendation-performance scores for 2010.

Sanjeev Rana

Age: 35<br />Country: South Korea<br />Credit firm: Deutsche Bank Research<br />Industries covered: Autos and auto parts, <br />shipbuilding and heavy machinery<br />Rank: 1<br />Score: 75.9

<b>Key call:</b><br />Kia Motors Corp. in May 2009. "At that time, most foreign brokerage analysts were negative because Kia had been a chronic problem child of Hyundai Motor Group," said Mr. Rana, noting that he was one of few analysts to put a positive rating on the stock early in 2009.

<b>2011 outlook:</b><br />Hyundai Motor Group, because of robust car demand in the U.S. and in emerging markets like Russia and Brazil. "They have right products that customers want and their brand recognition has improved tremendously," he said.

(Photo: Deutsche Bank)

Bekay Kim

Country: South Korea<br />Credit firm: Daishin Securities <br />Rank: 2<br />Score: 65.7

Young-il Kang

Age: 42<br />Country: South Korea<br />Credit firm: HMC Investment & Securities<br />Industries covered: Autos<br />Rank: 3<br />Score: 64

<b>Best pick of 2010:</b><br />"Hyundai & Kia makes money in America. Most people thought that Korean auto makers could not make money in America because of severe competition and low price. But I had a conviction that U.S. market's competition was getting easier due to low inventory level and Hyundai & Kia were making money thank to the incentives below industry average and volume effect."

<b>2011 outlook:</b><br />"Korean auto makers earning and M/S should be better than 2010. Japanese auto makers are damaged by the earthquake and they are not as dynamic as Koreans. Korean makers can easily accept business environmental change."

Techasiriwan Sirinattha

Country: Thailand<br />Credit firm: Kasikorn Securities <br />Industries covered: Banks, securities and insurance<br />Rank: 1<br />Score: 85.5

<b>Key call:</b><br />"Krung Thai Bank PCL in late 2009, as the bank began revamping its fusty image and promoted a new generation of management to run its operations. It returned 80% on the year."

<b>2011 outlook:</b><br />This year Ms. Sirinattha is taking a look at the country's larger lenders, including Siam Commercial Bank PCL. "That's where the upside could be now," she said.

(Photo: Kasikorn Securities)

Rahul Jain

Age: 29<br />Country: India<br />Credit firm: HDFC Securities <br />Industries covered: Banks and financial services<br />Rank: 2<br />Score: 64.4

<b>Best pick of 2010:</b><br />"We were bullish on PSU banks since the start of 2010 due to robust growth outlook, improved outlook on profitability and moderating concerns on asset quality. We initiated coverage on the PSU banks with a positive view. Our top call was Canara Bank, which we upgraded from hold to buy in July. The return from the stock was 64% based on the closing price on Dec. 31, and based on the max price achieved by the stock during the year the return was 108%."

<b>Worst pick of 2010:</b><br />"We initiated on IOB with a hold rating and maintained it throughout, even though the stock performed well mainly due to improving asset quality outlook. But given the higher restructured assets, we mainatained our hold rating with a relative underperform versus bankex."

<b>2011 outlook:</b><br />"Outlook for calendar year 2011 and fiscal year 2012 remains mixed. Fiscal year 2011 saw banks' margins peaking and with a sharper rise in deposit rates at the later part of 2010. However, lower pension-related costs and lower credit costs will keep the earnings growth momentum relatively healthy and banks should realize an earnings growth of 18% to 30% depending on individual banks."

Vijay Sarathi

Age: 41<br />Country: India<br />Credit firm: BNP Paribas Securities<br />Industries covered: Banks & non-banking finance <br />companies<br />Rank: 3<br />Score: 61.8

<b>Best pick of 2010:</b><br />The downgrade of banks in October 2010. "It was a very counter-consensus call when a majority of the Street opinion was in favor of buying banks. The sector corrected over 20% in the ensuing three months. We spotted the tightening liquidity situation ahead of others, which led to the sell-off."

<b>Worst pick of 2010:</b><br />Hold on SBI during May to September 2010 on concerns of rising bad loans. "The stock did very well during this period as bad loans recognition was delayed."

<b>2011 outlook:</b><br />"The next two to three months will be muted as rising inflation and rising interest rates do not augur well for banks. However, the later part of the year should again see renewed interest as valuations are very attractive for banks and bulk of the India-specific macro headwinds should be behind us then."

Brendan Fitzpatrick

Age: 35<br />Country: Australia<br />Credit firm: Deutsche Bank Research <br />Rank: 1<br />Score: 86.9

<b>Key call:</b><br />It was on a research trip""a site visit in the Philippines""that Mr. Fitzpatrick began to appreciate the fact that a gold mine had longevity beyond the defined reserves and subsequently assigned a buy rating to Medusa Mining Ltd. That stock returned 93% for the full year on a total return basis.

<b>Missed call:</b><br />Keeping Iluka Resources Ltd. of the mineral-sands sector on hold all year; the stock wound up returning 155%. "It was a scenario where commodity prices and industry outlook changed rapidly throughout the year," he said. The mineral sands market is an opaque one because there is no liquid market for the resources, just price indications offered by industry players. "It's been a little bit frustrating."

(Photo: Deutsche Bank)

Ray Chantry

Country: Australia<br />Credit firm: E L & C Baillieu <br />Industries covered: Resources<br />Rank: 2<br />Score: 74.9

<b>Best pick of 2010:</b><br />Iluka. Because of a new CEO and a new culture, the company got control of its own destiny in the zircon and titaniferous markets, he said.

<b>Worst pick of 2010:</b><br />ERA, because the worst cyclone season on record caught the Rio Tinto management by surprise.

<b>2011 outlook:</b><br />"2011 is as difficult a year as I have ever experienced with many conflicting signals. There are very few commodities with a two-year positive outlook and currency turmoil in mineral-producing countries just adds another dimension."

Tom Sartor

Age: 33<br />Country: Australia<br />Credit firm: RBS Morgans<br />Industries covered: Materials (coal and base metals)<br />Rank: 3<br />Score: 52.7

<b>Best pick of 2010:</b><br />PanAust. "We re-rated on the back of very strong operational improvements and rising copper prices."

<b>Worst pick of 2010:</b><br />"New Hope achieved only market returns during 2010 relative to its peers, which enjoy higher operating leverage to rising coal prices. 2011 has been a much tougher market with small-cap companies in particular suffering from volatility in global risk appetite."

<b>2011 outlook:</b><br />"We think investors need to be far more nimble in 2011 as coal prices correct off cyclical highs, cost and Australian dollar headwinds mount, and as macro risk factors drive risk-on risk-off trading in resource-exposed markets," he said. "We prefer the established producers with stable cost structures and strong cashflows."

Gauri Anand

Age: 29<br />Country: India<br />Credit firm: MF Global Sify Securities <br />Industries covered: Chemicals<br />Rank: 1<br />Score: 106.4

<b>Key call: </b><br />Phosphatics-related stocks. "We saw reforms for phosphatics much ahead of the industry," she said, explaining that the government deregulated the prices of phosphatics""nutrients containing phosphate that help plants grow""in February. "We continue to like the phosphatic fertilizer space, but we expect the stocks to consolidate given the splendid run last year."

<b>2011 outlook:</b><br />Stocks in the urea chemicals sector, which she believes the government is soon going to deregulate. Urea is a plant fertilizer that contains nitrogen. "Reform in urea, if delayed, may further threaten the existing nutrient imbalance in soil and risk productivity""something the government may want to avoid (when it) is battling the already-high food inflation," she said.

(Photo: MF Global Sify Securities)

Sang-do Choi

Age: 37<br />Country: South Korea<br />Credit firm: Bookook Securities <br />Industries covered: Chemicals<br />Rank: 2<br />Score: 97.9

<b>Best pick of 2010:</b><br />Korea Kumho Petrochemical Co., with a full-year return of more than 300%.

<b>Worst pick of 2010:</b><br />KPX Fine Chemical Co., with a full-year return of negative 2%.

<b>2011 outlook:</b><br />"The chemicals industry was bullish last year and the upside momentum will last through the first half of 2011 but it will likely to slow in the second half. That's because the stock prices of chemical stocks have already risen a lot amid economic recovery and high oil prices on strong demand. In addition to that, there are concerns that the economy may suffer a slowdown in advanced countries such as the U.S. in the latter half."

Eunjoo Shin

Age: 37<br />Country: South Korea<br />Credit firm: Korea Investment & Securities <br />Industries covered: Chemicals<br />Rank: 3<br />Score: 94.6

<b>Best pick of 2010:</b><br />SKC. "It was very different from the street consensus."

<b>Worst pick of 2010:</b><br />Honam petrochemical. "The stock price went not along with earnings."

<b>2011 outlook:</b><br />"Positive. Even though the steep rise of oil prices and China's tightening are challenging issues, ongoing growth of demand and limited supply additions bode well for the outlook of 2011."

John Park

Age: 43<br />Country: South Korea<br />Credit firm: Daishin Securities <br />Industries covered: Electronics and electronic <br />components<br />Rank: 1<br />Score: 36.2

<b>Key call:</b><br />Electronics-component maker LG Innotek Co., where he saw potential when the market was seeing mostly a cause for concern""increased capital spending following a merger with fellow parts maker LG Micron Ltd. in late 2009. Mr. Park's buy call returned nearly 50%.

<b>2011 outlook:</b><br />Mr. Park says smartphone competition was the biggest market topic in 2010, and he expects Korean electronics makers to continue to face an uphill battle. "Developing (one's) own software platform seems to be an inevitable strategy now," he said. "In that sense, Apple is expected to continue to cement (its) leadership in the premium markets with its smartphones and tablet devices in the next two or three years."

(Photo: Daishin Securities)

Shuichi Ide

Age: 33<br />Country: Japan<br />Credit firm: Mizuho Securities <br />Industries covered: Industrial electronics and <br />control/measuring equipment<br />Rank: 2<br />Score: 28.9

<b>Best pick of 2010:</b><br />Hitachi. "We raised our recommendation on Hitachi from neutral to outperform before the share price rallied in 2010. We expected Hitachi's companywide earnings to improve on strong demand for social infrastructure, and believed the company to be undervalued."

<b>Worst pick of 2010:</b><br />Yamatake. "We expected the building automation business to recover in FY3/11, but orders have been slower to recover than we had anticipated."

<b>2011 outlook:</b><br />"Post-earthquake restoration work will take priority over other investment. Businesses involved in thermal-power generation equipment should find themselves very busy, and we expect to see an increase in demand for the control equipment needed to restore operations at plants affected by the earthquake. In contrast, we expect to see a slowdown in IT investment and R&D spending."

<Title>Hiroyasu Sato </Title>

Age: 36<br />Country: Japan<br />Credit firm: Daiwa Securities Capital Markets<br />Industries covered: Electronics<br />Rank: 3<br />Score: 28.0

<Title>Pathik Gandotra </Title>

<b>2011 outlook:</b><br />"ICICI Bank had demonstrated in the last two years under the new management that it is able to become more profitable by not growing, by curtailing its growth," he said. "We believe this year it will demonstrate it can grow and still be profitable."

(Photo: Pathik Gandotra)

<Title>Alpesh Mehta </Title>

<Title>Sarika Lohra </Title>

Country: India<br />Credit firm: Kotak PCG <br />Rank: 3<br />Score: 54.4

<Title>Ploenjai Jirajarus </Title>

<b>Key call:</b><br />Charoen Pokphand Foods PCL, an agribusiness giant that operates major farming ventures in China and Thailand and also markets its own precooked meat products across Asia and Europe under the CP brand. Its return for the year was 125%.

But the trend toward quality food producers remains intact, Ms. Ploenjai said, and she continues to like the growth prospects of Charoen Pokphand Foods and Thai Union Frozen.

<Title>Chee Yoon Yew </Title>

Age: 47<br />Country: Malaysia<br />Credit firm: Kim Eng <br />Industries covered: Banks, telecommunications, <br />property, food and beverages<br />Rank: 2<br />Score: 72.1

<Title>Khair Mirza </Title>

Age: 35<br />Country: Malaysia<br />Credit firm: Maybank Investment Bank <br />Industries covered: Aviation, food & beverages, retail, <br />telecommunications and tobacco <br />Rank: 3<br />Score: 61.3

<b>Best pick of 2010:</b><br />"Reiterating our overweight call on the wider consumer sector, focusing on the F&B counters that would most benefit from a reduction in subsidies, relative to its competitors. This was a counter-intuitive and market-contrarian call that continues to bear fruit. In the most recent and ongoing first-quarter 2011 results season, market followers have begun to report lower quarter-on-quarter and year-on-year earnings whilst our top picks continue to outshine the market with year-on-year double-digit earnings growth. "

<b>2011 outlook:</b><br />"2011 remains a stock-pickers' haven. Personally, I would remain bullish on counters that are either market-leaders in their respective niches or non-market leaders that consistently raise their market shares both in relative and absolute terms. I would especially like such counters that would represent undemanding investments at current prices that represent significant market contrarian calls."

<Title>Bin Li </Title>

Country: Hong Kong<br />Credit firm: Morgan Stanley<br />Rank: 1<br />Score: 89.9<br />

<b>key call:</b><br />United Laboratories International Holdings Ltd., which posted returns of close to 300% in 2010. Behind the rise was the strong performance of the company's chemical commodity business. The company's drug business also benefited from China's 2009 National Drug Reimbursement List, which confers insurance reimbursement for medicines on the list. United Laboratories produces human insulin products for a market where the number of people with diabetes is growing rapidly, Mr. Li said.

<b>2011 outlook:</b><br />The National Drug Reimbursement List continues to drive his outlook for the health-care industry in China. This year, he favors companies including U.S.-listed Simcere Pharmaceutical Group and 3Sbio Inc., and Hong Kong-listed Lee's Pharmaceutical Holdings Ltd., Sihuan Pharmaceutical Holdings Group Ltd., and Sino Biopharmaceutical Ltd.

(Photo: Morgan Stanley)

<Title>Vikas Sonawale </Title>

Age: 34<br />Country: India<br />Credit firm: Religare Hichens Harrison (India)<br />Industries covered: Pharma and health care<br />Rank: 2<br />Score: 53.6

<b>Best pick of 2010:</b><br />Piramal Health Care. "This company sold its domestic pharma business to Abbott in the U.S., and the value was huge. The cash value was more than the market cap of the company. In spite of this, we were among first to say sell, as we thought the cash investment was too high. In the pharma space, everyone was positive so it was difficult to find a sell call."

<b>2011 outlook:</b><br />"Very positive from an earnings perspective. Calendar year 2011 is attractive for generics companies, supported by strong growth in India, and will remain strong through the year. Pharma companies in India are producing generics for India and elsewhere in the world, we expect them to have 18%-20% growth in 2011."

<Title>Nimish Desai </Title>

Age: 40<br />Country: India<br />Credit firm: Motilal Oswal Securities <br />Industries covered: Health care<br />Rank: 3<br />Score: 47.1
